\mathrm{pH}= \mathrm{p}K_a + \log\frac{[\text{HPO}_4^{2-}]}{[\text{H}_2\text{PO}_4^-]} .
\]

For the \(\text{H}_2\text{PO}_4^- \rightleftharpoons \text{HPO}_4^{2-}+ \text{H}^+\) equilibrium,  

\[
pK_a = 7.2 .
\]

Thus  

\[
\frac{[\text{HPO}_4^{2-}]}{[\text{H}_2\text{PO}_4^-]}
=10^{\mathrm{pH}-pK_a}
=10^{6.8-7.2}
=10^{-0.4}
\approx 0.40 .
\]

\[
\boxed{0.40}
\]

question: Explore the bicarbonate/carbonic acid buffering system of blood plasma   At \( 37^\circ\text{C} \), if the plasma pH is 7.4 and the plasma concentration of \( \text{HCO}_3^- \) is 15 mM, what is the plasma concentration of \( \text{H}_2\text{CO}_3 \)? What is the plasma concentration of \( \text{CO}_{2(\text{dissolved})} \)? If metabolic activity changes the concentration of \( \text{CO}_{2 \ (\text{dissolved})} \) to 3 mM, and \( [\text{HCO}_3^-] \) remains at 15 mM, what is the pH of the plasma?
llm_answer:
The bicarbonate–carbonic‑acid system in plasma is described by the Henderson–Hasselbalch relation  

\[
\mathrm{pH}=pK_a+\log\frac{[\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]}{[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]},
\qquad pK_a\;(37^{\circ}\mathrm{C})\approx 6.1 .
\]

---

### 1.  Concentration of \(\mathbf{H_2CO_3}\) when \(\mathrm{pH}=7.4\) and \([\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]=15\;\text{mM}\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
7.4 &= 6.1+\log\frac{15}{[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]}\\[4pt]
\log\frac{15}{[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]} &= 1.3\\[4pt]
\frac{15}{[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]} &= 10^{1.3}\approx 20\\[4pt]
[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}] &= \frac{15}{20}\;\text{mM}\approx 0.75\;\text{mM}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{0.75\ \text{mM}}
\]

---

### 2.  Concentration of dissolved \(\mathbf{CO_2}\)

In the plasma buffer the species \(\mathrm{CO_2 (aq)}\) and \(\mathrm{H_2CO_3}\) are inter‑convertible and are usually treated as a single “acid” species. Hence  

\[
[\mathrm{CO_2\;(dissolved)}]\;=\;[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]
\]

\[
\boxed{0.75\ \text{mM}}
\]

---

### 3.  New pH when \([\mathrm{CO_\;(dissolved)}]=3\;\text{mM}\) (while \([\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]=15\;\text{mM}\))

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{pH} &= 6.1+\log\frac{15}{3}\\
            &= 6.1+\log(5)\\
            &= 6.1+0.699\approx 6.80 .
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{6.80}
\]

question: Calculating the effect of pH on \(\Delta G^\circ\)   ATP hydrolysis at pH 7.0 is accompanied by release of a hydrogen ion to the medium   $$\text{ATP}^{4-} + \text{H}_2\text{O} \rightleftharpoons \text{ADP}^{3-} + \text{HPO}_4^{2-} + \text{H}^+$$   If the \(\Delta G'^\circ\) for this reaction is \(-30.5 \ \text{kJ/mol}\), what is \(\Delta G^\circ\) (that is, the free energy change for the same reaction with all components, including \(\text{H}^+\), at a standard state of \(1 \ M\))?
llm_answer:
The transformed standard Gibbs energy \(\Delta G'^{\circ}\) is defined for a reference \([\mathrm{H}^{+}]=10^{-7}\,\text{M}\) (pH 7).  
For a reaction that produces one mole of \(\mathrm{H}^{+}\) (\(\nu_{\mathrm{H}^{+}}=+1\)) the relationship between \(\Delta G^{\circ}\) (all species at 1 M) and \(\Delta G'^{\circ}\) is  

\[
\Delta G'^{\circ}= \Delta G^{\circ}+RT\ln a_{\mathrm{H}^{+}}^{\; \nu_{\mathrm{H}^{+}}}
               = \Delta G^{\circ}+RT\ln(10^{-7}) .
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}= \Delta G'^{\circ}-RT\ln(10^{-7}).
\]

At \(T=298\ \text{K}\),

\[
RT = (8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(298\ \text{K}) = 2.48\times10^{3}\ \text{J mol}^{-1},
\]

\[
\ln(10^{-7}) = -7\ln 10 = -7(2.302585) = -16.118.
\]

Thus  

\[
RT\ln(10^{-7}) = (2.48\times10^{3}\ \text{J mol}^{-1})(-16.118) \approx -3.99\times10^{4}\ \text{J mol}^{-1}
                = -39.9\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

Finally,

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}= -30.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1} - (-39.9\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1})
                \approx 9.4\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{9.4}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Calculating \( K_{\text{eq}} \) and \( \Delta G \) from concentrations   An enzymatic hydrolysis of fructose - 1 - P   $$\text{Fructose-1-P} + \text{H}_2\text{O} \rightleftharpoons \text{fructose} + \text{P}_i$$   was allowed to proceed to equilibrium at \( 25^\circ\text{C} \). The original concentration of fructose - 1 - P was \( 0.2 \ M \), but when the system had reached equilibrium the concentration of fructose 1 - P was only \( 6.52 \times 10^{-5} \ M \). Calculate the standard free energy of hydrolysis of fructose 1 - P.

A teenager can grow 4 in. in a year during a "growth spurt". Assuming that the increase in height is due to vertical growth of collagen fibers (in bone), calculate the number of collagen helix turns synthesized per strand per minute.
llm_answer:
The increase in height is  

\[
\Delta h = 4\ \text{in}=4(2.54\ \text{cm})=10.16\ \text{cm}=1.016\times10^{8}\ \text{nm}.
\]

A collagen triple‑helix advances \(0.86\ \text{nm}\) per helical turn (3 residues × 0.286 nm per residue).  
Hence the number of turns that must be added to achieve the growth is  

\[
N_{\text{turns}}=\frac{\Delta h}{0.86\ \text{nm}}
               =\frac{1.016\times10^{8}\ \text{nm}}{0.86\ \text{nm}}
               \approx 1.18\times10^{8}\ \text{turns}.
\]

During a growth spurt the time available is one year:

\[
t = 365\ \text{days}\times 24\ \text{h day}^{-1}\times 60\ \text{min h}^{-1}
   = 5.256\times10^{5}\ \text{min}.
\]

Thus the synthesis rate per collagen strand is  

\[
\text{turns per minute}
   =\frac{N_{\text{turns}}}{t}
   =\frac{1.18\times10^{8}}{5.256\times10^{5}}
   \approx 2.25\times10^{2}\ \text{turns min}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{2.25\times10^{2}}\ \text{turns/min}
\]

question: A 0.2 - g sample of amylopectin was analyzed to determine the fraction of the total glucose residues that are branch points in the structure. The sample was exhaustively methylated and then digested, yielding 50 Ã×mol of 2,3 - dimethylglucose and 0.4 Ã×mol of 1,2,3,6 - tetramethylglucose. How many reducing ends does this amylopectin have?

Calculating \( K_{\text{eq}} \) and \( \Delta G \) from concentrations   An enzymatic hydrolysis of fructose - 1 - P   $$\text{Fructose-1-P} + \text{H}_2\text{O} \rightleftharpoons \text{fructose} + \text{P}_i$$   was allowed to proceed to equilibrium at \( 25^\circ\text{C} \). The original concentration of fructose - 1 - P was \( 0.2 \ M \), but when the system had reached equilibrium the concentration of fructose 1 - P was only \( 6.52 \times 10^{-5} \ M \). Calculate the equilibrium constant for this reaction.
The dissociation constant for a particular protein dimer is 1 micromolar. Calculate the free energy difference for the monomer to dimer transition.
llm_answer:
The standard free‑energy change for the monomer ⇌ dimer equilibrium is related to the dissociation constant by  

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}=RT\ln K_{\mathrm d}
\]

Using \(R = 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\) and \(T = 298\;\text{K}\),

\[
RT = 8.314 \times 298 = 2.48\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\ln K_{\mathrm d}= \ln (1\times10^{-6}) = -13.8155
\]

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}= (2.48\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1})(-13.8155)
               = -3.42\times10^{4}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
               = -34.2\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{-34.2}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI - MS) of the polypeptide chain of myoglobin yielded a series of \(m/z\) peaks (similar to those shown in Figure 5.21 for aerolysin K). Two successive peaks had \(m/z\) values of 1304.7 and 1413.2, respectively. Calculate the mass of the myoglobin polypeptide chain from these data.
llm_answer:
In an ESI‑MS spectrum a protein ion of charge \(z\) appears at  

\[
\frac{m}{z}= \frac{M+z\,m_{\mathrm H}}{z}= \frac{M}{z}+m_{\mathrm H},
\]

where  

* \(M\) = neutral mass of the protein (Da)  
* \(m_{\mathrm H}=1.0073\;\text{Da}\) = mass of a proton.

For two **consecutive** charge states the peaks differ by one unit of charge.  
Let the lower‑\(m/z\) peak (1304.7) correspond to charge \(z+1\) and the higher‑\(m/z\) peak (1413.2) to charge \(z\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
1304.7 &= \frac{M}{z+1}+m_{\mathrm H}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad 
M = (1304.7-m_{\mathrm H})(z+1),\\[4pt]
1413.2 &= \frac{M}{z}+m_{\mathrm H}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad 
M = (1413.2-m_{\mathrm H})z .
\end{aligned}
\]

Subtract the two equations:

\[
1413.2-1304.7 = M\!\left(\frac{1}{z}-\frac{1}{z+1}\right)
               = \frac{M}{z(z+1)} .
\]

Hence  

\[
M = (1413.2-1304.7)\,z(z+1)=108.5\,z(z+1).
\]

The integer value of \(z\) that gives a realistic protein mass is found by trial:

\[
\begin{aligned}
z=12 &\;\Rightarrow\; M =108.5\times12\times13 = 1.69\times10^{4}\,\text{Da},\\
z=11 &\;\Rightarrow\; M =108.5\times11\times12 = 1.43\times10^{4}\,\text{Da}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Using the measured \(m/z\) values with the exact proton mass (\(m_{\mathrm H}=1.0073\) Da) gives

\[
\begin{aligned}
z &= \frac{1304.7-1.0073}{1413.2-1304.7}=13,\\
M &= (1304.7-1.0073)\times13 = 1.6948\times10^{4}\;\text{Da}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus the mass of the myoglobin polypeptide chain is

\[
\boxed{1.69\times10^{4}\ \text{Da}}.
\]

question: Phospholipid lateral motion in membranes is characterized by a diffusion coefficient of about \(1 \times 10^{-8} \ \text{cm}^2/\text{sec}\). The distance traveled in two dimensions (in the membrane) in a given time is \(r = (4Dt)^{1/2}\), where \(r\) is the distance traveled in centimeters, \(D\) is the diffusion coefficient, and \(t\) is the time during which diffusion occurs. Calculate the distance traveled by a phospholipid in a bilayer in 10 msec (milliseconds).

Consider a phospholipid vesicle containing \(10 \ \text{mM}\ \text{Na}^+\) ions. The vesicle is bathed in a solution that contains \(52 \ \text{mM}\ \text{Na}^+\) ions, and the electrical potential difference across the vesicle membrane \(\Delta \psi = \psi_{\text{outside}} - \psi_{\text{inside}} = -30 \ \text{mV}\). What is the electrochemical potential at \(25^\circ\text{C}\) for \(\text{Na}^+\) ions?
llm_answer:
The electrochemical potential difference for Na⁺ across the membrane is  

\[
\Delta\mu_{\text{Na}^+}=RT\ln\!\frac{[\text{Na}^+]_{\text{out}}}{[\text{Na}^+]_{\text{in}}}+zF\Delta\psi
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
RT &= (8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(298\;\text{K}) = 2.48\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1},\\[4pt]
\ln\!\frac{52}{10} &= \ln(5.2)=1.6486,\\[4pt]
RT\ln\!\frac{[\text{Na}^+]_{\text{out}}}{[\text{Na}^+]_{\text{in}}} &= 2.48\times10^{3}\times1.6486 = 4.09\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1},\\[4pt]
zF\Delta\psi &= (1)(96485\;\text{C mol}^{-1})(-0.030\;\text{V}) = -2.89\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\Delta\mu_{\text{Na}^+}=4.09\times10^{3}\;-\;2.89\times10^{3}=1.19\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
=1.19\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{1.19}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: The purple patches of the Halobacterium halobium membrane, which contain the protein bacteriorhodopsin, are approximately 75% protein and 25% lipid. If the protein molecular weight is 26,000 and an average phospholipid has a molecular weight of 800, calculate the phospholipid to protein mole ratio.
If 80% of the base pairs in a duplex DNA molecule (12.5 kbp) are in the B - conformation and 20% are in the Z - conformation, what is the long dimension of the molecule?

The genome of the Mycoplasma genitalium consists of 523 genes, encoding 484 proteins, in just 580,074 base pairs (Table 1.6). What fraction of the M. genitalium genes encodes proteins? What do you think the other genes encode? If the fraction of base pairs devoted to protein - coding genes is the same as the fraction of the total genes that they represent, what is the average number of base pairs per protein - coding gene? If it takes 3 base pairs to specify an amino acid in a protein, how many amino acids are found in the average M. genitalium protein? If each amino acid contributes on average 120 daltons to the mass of a protein, what is the mass of an average M. genitalium protein? What fraction of the M. genitalium genes encodes proteins?

The haploid human genome consists of \(3 \times 10^9\) base pairs. Using the logic in problem 15, one can calculate the minimum length of a unique DNA sequence expected to occur by chance just once in the human genome. That is, what is the length of a double - stranded DNA whose expected frequency of occurrence is once in the haploid human genome?
llm_answer:
The expected number of occurrences of a specific DNA sequence of length \(L\) in a random genome of size \(N\) base pairs is  

\[
\text{E}=\frac{N}{4^{L}}\; .
\]

Setting this expectation equal to one and solving for \(L\):

\[
\frac{N}{4^{L}} = 1 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad 4^{L}=N
\]

\[
L = \log_{4} N = \frac{\ln N}{\ln 4}.
\]

For the haploid human genome \(N = 3\times10^{9}\) bp,

\[
L = \frac{\ln (3\times10^{9})}{\ln 4}
   \approx \frac{21.822}{1.3863}
   \approx 15.75 .
\]

Since the length must be an integer number of base pairs, we take the next whole number:

\[
L = \approx 16\ \text{base pairs}.
\]

\[
\boxed{16\ \text{bp}}
\]

question: If \( V_{max} = 100 \ \mu\text{mol}/\text{mL©{sec} \) and \( K_m = 2 \ \text{mM} \), what is the velocity of the reaction when \([S] = 20 \ \text{mM}\)?
A PO3- radical produces a pair of lines separated by 280 MHz with giso = 2.005. Calculate the higher one of expected resonant field positions of both lines in the X-band EPR spectrum (ôé = 9.5 GHz).

As Pauling's method gives a difference in electronegativity it is necessary to choose a reference point in order to gain values for individual elements. Pauling originally chose hydrogen as the reference, with a value of 2.20. The difference in electronegativity between \ce{Cl} and \ce{H} is 0.962. Using the reference, what is the elctronegativity of chlorine?

Boron nitride has a wurtzite structure (w-BN). The unit cell of w-BN is a right rhombic prism, with cell parameters of d = \pu{2.54 \A} and e = \pu{3.63 \A} and interior angles of \pu{60 deg} and \pu{120 deg}. What is the number of B atoms in the unit cell of w-BN?
What is the spin-only magnetic moment (in units of Bohr-magnetons) for the low-spin case of the metal complex \ce{RhCl(CO)(PPh3)2}?
llm_answer:
The spin‑only magnetic moment is given by  

\[
\mu_{\text{so}}=\sqrt{n(n+2)}\;\text{BM},
\]

where \(n\) is the number of unpaired electrons.  

For \(\ce{RhCl(CO)(PPh_3)_2}\):

* Rh is in the +1 oxidation state (Cl = –1, CO and PPh\(_3\) are neutral).  
* Rh(I) is a \(d^{8}\) metal ion.  
* In the low‑spin (square‑planar) \(d^{8}\) configuration all electrons are paired, so \(n=0\).

Hence  

\[
\mu_{\text{so}}=\sqrt{0(0+2)}=0\;\text{BM}.
\]

\[
\boxed{0}\ \text{BM}
\]

question: The \( k_{\text{cat}} \) for alkaline phosphatase - catalyzeded hydrolysis of methylphosphate is approximately 14/sec at pH 8 and \( 25^\circ\text{C} \). The rate constant for the uncatalyzed hydrolysis of methylphosphate under the same conditions is approximately \( 1\times10^{-15} \)/sec. What is the difference in the activation free energies of these two reactions?

Pauling used thermodynamic data to calculate the difference in electronegativity between two atoms A and B, $X(A) - X(B) = 0.102 \sqrt{(Bd(AB) - \frac{(Bd(AA)+Bd(BB)}{2})}$ , where Bd represents the bond dissociation energies, in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}, of the A-A, B-B and A-B bonds. What is the difference in electronegativity between \ce{Cl} and \ce{H}, given that Bd(\ce{H2}) = \pu{432 kJ mol^{-1}}, Bd(\ce{Cl2}) = \pu{244 kJ mol^{-1}} and Bd(\ce{HCl}) = \pu{427 kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_answer:
The Pauling electronegativity difference is  

\[
X(A)-X(B)=0.102\sqrt{\,\text{Bd}(AB)-\frac{\text{Bd}(AA)+\text{Bd}(BB)}{2}\,}.
\]

For the pair \(\ce{Cl}\) (A) and \(\ce{H}\) (B) we insert the given bond‑dissociation energies:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Bd}(\ce{Cl–H}) &= \pu{427\ kJ\ mol^{-1}},\\[2pt]
\text{Bd}(\ce{Cl–Cl}) &= \pu{244\ kJ\ mol^{-1}},\\[2pt]
\text{Bd}(\ce{H–H})  &= \pu{432\ kJ\ mol^{-1}}.
\end{aligned}
\]

First compute the average of the homonuclear bond energies:

\[
\frac{\text{Bd}(\ce{Cl–Cl})+\text{Bd}(\ce{H–H})}{2}
   =\frac{244+432}{2}
   =\frac{676}{2}
   =\pu{338\ kJ\ mol^{-1}}.
\]

Now evaluate the term inside the square‑root:

\[
\text{Bd}(\ce{Cl–H})-\frac{\text{Bd}(\ce{Cl–Cl})+\text{Bd}(\ce{H–H})}{2}
   = 427-338
   = \pu{89\ kJ\ mol^{-1}}.
\]

Take the square root:

\[
\sqrt{89}\approx 9.433.
\]

Finally multiply by the factor \(0.102\):

\[
X(\ce{Cl})-X(\ce{H}) = 0.102 \times 9.433 \approx 0.962.
\]

Rounded to two significant figures, the electronegativity difference is  

\[
\boxed{0.96}
\]

question: What is the oxidation number of the metal in the compound \ce{[Pt(NH3)2Cl4]}?
llm_answer:
The complex \(\ce{[Pt(NH3)2Cl4]}\) is neutral.  
Ammonia (\(\ce{NH3}\)) is a neutral ligand, while each chloride (\(\ce{Cl^-}\)) contributes \(-1\).

Let the oxidation number of Pt be \(x\).

\[
x + 2(0) + 4(-1) = 0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad x - 4 = 0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad x = +4
\]

\[
\boxed{+4}
\]

question: The buoyant density of DNA is proportional to its (G + C) content. (G:C base pairs have more atoms per volume than A:T base pairs.) Calculate the density (\(\rho\)) of avian tubercle bacillus DNA from the data presented in Table 10.1 and the equation \(\rho = 1.660 + 0.098\ (\text{GC})\), where \(\text{GC}\) is the mole fraction of (G + C) in DNA.
llm_answer:
The buoyant density is obtained from  

\[
\rho = 1.660 + 0.098\;(\text{GC}),
\]

where \(\text{GC}\) is the mole fraction of guanine + cytosine.  
From Table 10.1 the GC content of avian tubercle bacillus DNA is  

\[
\text{GC}=0.68.
\]

Hence  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\rho &= 1.660 + 0.098 \times 0.68 \\
     &= 1.660 + 0.06664 \\
     &= 1.72664\;\text{g mL}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Rounded to three significant figures,

\[
\boxed{1.727}\ \text{g/mL}.
\]

question: A 0.2 - g sample of amylopectin was analyzed to determine the fraction of the total glucose residues that are branch points in the structure. The sample was exhaustively methylated and then digested, yielding 50 Ã×mol of 2,3 - dimethylglucose and 0.4 Ã×mol of 1,2,3,6 - tetramethylglucose. What fraction of the total residues are branch points?

llm_answer:
The oxidation state \(x\) of rhenium is found from the overall charge balance:

\[
x + 9(-1) = -2 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad x - 9 = -2 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad x = +7
\]

\boxed{+7}

question: Boron nitride has a cubic form(c-BN). The unit cell of c-BN is cubic, with cell parameters of a = \pu{3.63 Angstrom}. What is the density of c-BN in \pu{g cm^{-3}}?
llm_answer:
The density \(\rho\) of a crystalline solid is  

\[
\rho=\frac{\text{mass of the unit cell}}{\text{volume of the unit cell}} .
\]

---

**1. Unit‑cell volume**

\[
a = 3.63\ \text{\AA}=3.63\times10^{-8}\ \text{cm}
\]

\[
V_{\text{cell}} = a^{3}= (3.63\times10^{-8}\,\text{cm})^{3}
               = 3.63^{3}\times10^{-24}\,\text{cm}^{3}
               \approx 4.786\times10^{-23}\ \text{cm}^{3}.
\]

---

**2. Mass of the unit cell**

Cubic BN (zinc‑blende) contains 4 formula units per conventional cell.  
Molar mass of BN:

\[
M_{\text{BN}} = M_{\text{B}} + M_{\text{N}}
               = 10.81 + 14.01 = 24.82\ \text{g mol}^{-1}.
\]

Mass per unit cell:

\[
m_{\text{cell}} = 4\,M_{\text{BN}}/N_{\!A}
                = \frac{4 \times 24.82\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}{6.022\times10^{23}\ \text{mol}^{-1}}
                \approx 1.65\times10^{-22}\ \text{g}.
\]

---

**3. Density**

\[
\rho = \frac{m_{\text{cell}}}{V_{\text{cell}}}
     = \frac{1.65\times10^{-22}\ \text{g}}{4.786\times10^{-23}\ \text{cm}^{3}}
     \approx 3.44\ \text{g cm}^{-3}.
\]

\[
\boxed{3.44}\ \text{g cm}^{-3}
\]

question: What is the oxidation number of the metal in the compound \ce{[Co(C2O4)2Cl2]^{3-}}?
llm_answer:
The overall charge on the complex ion is \(-3\).

Let the oxidation number of cobalt be \(x\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Charge from ligands:}&\quad
2\;\text{oxalate}^{2-}=2(-2)=-4\\
&\quad 2\;\text{Cl}^{-}=2(-1)=-2\\
\text{Total ligand charge}&=-4-2=-6
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus

\[
x + (-6) = -3 \;\Longrightarrow\; x = +3.
\]

\[
\boxed{+3}
\]

question: Talc (\ce{Mg3Si4H2O12}) is a mineral which contains hydroxide ions in addition to silicates. The formula of the silicate anion in talc is \ce{[SixO10]^{4-}}. What is the value of x?
llm_answer:
The silicate anion \(\ce{[Si_{x}O_{10}]^{4-}}\) must have a net charge of \(-4\).

Assign the usual oxidation numbers: \(\text{Si}=+4\) and \(\text{O}=-2\).

\[
\text{Total charge}=x(+4)+10(-2)=4x-20.
\]

Set this equal to the known charge \(-4\):

\[
4x-20=-4 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad 4x=16 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad x=4.
\]

\[
\boxed{4}
\]

question: To make silica gel, solid silicon dioxide must be reacted in 1:2 ratio with sodium carbonate at \pu{1500 deg C}. This reaction forms salt \ce{Na4SiO4} and colorless gas \ce{COx}. What is x?
llm_answer:
The balanced reaction for the given 1 : 2 molar ratio is  

\[
\ce{SiO2 + 2 Na2CO3 -> Na4SiO4 + 2 CO2}
\]

The gaseous product is carbon dioxide, \(\ce{CO2}\). Hence  

\[
x = 2
\]

\[
\boxed{2}
\]

question: Boron nitride has a cubic form(c-BN). The unit cell of c-BN is cubic, with cell parameters of a = \pu{3.63 Angstrom}. What is the volume of the c-BN unit cell in \pu{cm^{3}}?
llm_answer:
The volume of a cubic unit cell is  

\[
V = a^{3}.
\]

Convert the lattice parameter from ångströms to centimeters:

\[
a = 3.63\ \text{\AA}=3.63\times10^{-8}\ \text{cm}.
\]

Hence  

\[
V = (3.63\times10^{-8}\ \text{cm})^{3}
   = 3.63^{3}\times10^{-24}\ \text{cm}^{3}
   = 4.78\times10^{-23}\ \text{cm}^{3}.
\]

\[
\boxed{4.78\times10^{-23}}\ \text{cm}^{3}
\]

question: To calculate electronegativity of an element, Mulliken calculated the value from the first ionization energy (\ce{E_{i}}) and first electron affinity (\ce{E_{ea}}) of an atom, $X(A) = 0.00197(E_{i} + E_{ea}) + 0.19$, where \ce{E_{i} }and \ce{E_{ea}} are in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the Mulliken electronegativity of nitrogen given that \ce{E_{i}}(N) = \pu{14.5 eV} and \ce{E_{ea}}(N) = \pu{6.80 kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_answer:
The Mulliken electronegativity is  

\[
X(N)=0.00197\,(E_i+E_{ea})+0.19
\]

First convert the ionization energy from eV to kJ mol\(^{-1}\):

\[
E_i = 14.5\;\text{eV}\times 96.485\;\frac{\text{kJ}}{\text{mol·eV}}
      = 1.399\times10^{3}\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

The electron affinity is already in kJ mol\(^{-1}\):

\[
E_{ea}=6.80\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

Now sum the two energies:

\[
E_i+E_{ea}=1.399\times10^{3}+6.80=1.4058\times10^{3}\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

Insert into the Mulliken formula:

\[
\begin{aligned}
X(N) &=0.00197\,(1.4058\times10^{3})+0.19\\
     &=2.7695+0.19\\
     &=2.9595\;\approx\;2.96
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{2.96}
\]

question: What is the oxidation number of the metal in the compound \ce{[ZrF7]^{3-}}?
llm_answer:
The oxidation state \(x\) of zirconium is found from the overall charge balance:

\[
x + 7(-1) = -3 \;\Longrightarrow\; x - 7 = -3 \;\Longrightarrow\; x = +4.
\]

\[
\boxed{+4}
\]

question: What is the spin-only magnetic moment (in units of Bohr-magnetons) for the low-spin case of the metal complex tetramethylamine diaquacopper(II) ion?
llm_answer:
The Cu(II) ion is \(d^{9}\).  
In an octahedral (or square‑planar) low‑spin field the electron configuration is \(t_{2g}^{6}e_{g}^{3}\), giving **one unpaired electron** (\(n = 1\)).

The spin‑only magnetic moment is  

\[
\mu_{\text{so}}=\sqrt{n(n+2)}\;\text{BM}
               =\sqrt{1(1+2)}\;\text{BM}
               =\sqrt{3}\;\text{BM}.
\]

\[
\boxed{\sqrt{3}}\ \text{BM}
\]

question: Calculate the solubility of $\ce{BaSO_{4}}$ at 298 K in g per 100 g of water given that $K_{\text{sp}} = 1.07\times 10^{-10}$.
reference: Inorganic Chemistry _ Edition 4 -- Prof Catherine Housecroft, Alan G_ Sharpe -- 4th ed_, Harlow, England, New York, England, 2012 -- Pearson Education, 7.13
llm_answer:
The dissolution equilibrium is  

\[
\ce{BaSO4(s) <=> Ba^{2+}(aq) + SO4^{2-}(aq)}
\]

For a sparingly soluble salt that dissociates 1:1, the solubility \(s\) (mol L\(^{-1}\)) satisfies  

\[
K_{\text{sp}}=[\ce{Ba^{2+}}][\ce{SO4^{2-}}]=s^{2}
\]

\[
s=\sqrt{K_{\text{sp}}}= \sqrt{1.07\times10^{-10}}
      =\sqrt{1.07}\times10^{-5}
      \approx 1.03\times10^{-5}\ \text{mol L}^{-1}
\]

Assuming the solution is dilute, the volume of 100 g of water is essentially  

\[
V \approx \frac{100\ \text{g}}{1.00\ \text{g mL}^{-1}} = 100\ \text{mL}=0.10\ \text{L}
\]

Moles of \(\ce{BaSO4}\) that dissolve in this volume:

\[
n = sV = (1.03\times10^{-5}\ \text{mol L}^{-1})(0.10\ \text{L})
      = 1.03\times10^{-6}\ \text{mol}
\]

Molar mass of \(\ce{BaSO4}\):

\[
M = 137.33\ (\text{Ba}) + 32.07\ (\text{S}) + 4\times16.00\ (\text{O})
    = 233.4\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

Mass dissolved:

\[
m = nM = (1.03\times10^{-6}\ \text{mol})(233.4\ \text{g mol}^{-1})
    \approx 2.4\times10^{-4}\ \text{g}
\]

Hence the solubility of \(\ce{BaSO4}\) at 298 K is  

\[
\boxed{2.4\times10^{-4}\ \text{g per 100 g H}_2\text{O}}
\]

question: The ligand-field splitting energy (LFSE) is computed as $LFSE=-0.4\cdot Dq \cdot n+0.6 \cdot Dq \cdot m$ with $n$ being the number of electrons in t2g d orbitals ($\mathrm{d}_{xz}$, $\mathrm{d}_{yz}$ and $\mathrm{d}_{xy}$), $m$ the number of electrons in eg d orbitals ($\mathrm{d}_{x^2-y^2}$ and $\mathrm{d_{z^2}}$), and Dq the ligand field splitting parameter. What is the value of LFSE in terms of Dq for the low-spin case in the metal complex tetramethylamine diaquacopper(II) ion?
llm_answer:
The Cu(II) ion is \(d^{9}\).  
In an octahedral field the low‑spin arrangement fills the three \(t_{2g}\) orbitals completely (6 electrons) and places the remaining three electrons in the two \(e_g\) orbitals:

\[
n = 6,\qquad m = 3 .
\]

Insert these values into the LFSE expression:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{LFSE} &= -0.4\,Dq\,n + 0.6\,Dq\,m \\
            &= -0.4\,Dq\,(6) + 0.6\,Dq\,(3) \\
            &= -2.4\,Dq + 1.8\,Dq \\
            &= -0.6\,Dq .
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{-0.6\,Dq}
\]

question: When oleic acid glyceride is metabolized in the human body, the following reaction occurs:   $$\ce{C_{57}H_{104}O_{6}(s) + 80O_{2}(g) = 57CO_{2}(g) + 52H_{2}O(l)}$$   $\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus} = -3.35\times10^{4}\ \text{kJ¡¤mol}^{-1}$. Calculate the reaction progress when 1 kg of this fat is consumed, and how much heat will be released.
llm_answer:
The amount of triglyceride that corresponds to 1 kg is obtained from its molar mass  

\[
M(\ce{C_{57}H_{104}O_{6}})=57(12.011)+104(1.008)+6(15.999)\approx 8.85\times10^{2}\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
n=\frac{m}{M}= \frac{1000\ \text{g}}{8.85\times10^{2}\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}
      \approx 1.13\ \text{mol}
\]

Thus the extent of reaction (reaction progress) for 1 kg of the fat is  

\[
\boxed{1.13}\ \text{mol}
\]

The standard enthalpy change for the oxidation of one mole of the triglyceride is  

\[
\Delta_r H^\ominus = -3.35\times10^{4}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

Hence the heat released when the 1 kg sample is completely oxidised is  

\[
q = n\,\Delta_r H^\ominus = (1.13\ \text{mol})(-3.35\times10^{4}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1})
    \approx -3.78\times10^{4}\ \text{kJ}
\]

The magnitude of the heat liberated is  

\[
\boxed{3.78\times10^{4}}\ \text{kJ}
\]

question: A certain amount of ammonium chloride decomposes upon heating according to the following equation:   $$\ce{NH_{4}Cl(s)\rightleftharpoons NH_{3}(g) + HCl(g)}$$   It is known that for the reaction, \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}=161\ \text{kJ¡¤mol}^{-1}\) and \(\Delta_{r}S_{m}^{\ominus}=250\ \text{J¡¤mol}^{-1}¡¤\text{K}^{-1}\). Try to calculate the total pressure (kPa) of the system when equilibrium is reached at 700 K.
llm_answer:
The equilibrium constant in terms of pressure is  

\[
K_{p}=e^{-\Delta G^{\ominus}/RT}=e^{-(\Delta H^{\ominus}-T\Delta S^{\ominus})/RT}
\]

\[
\Delta H^{\ominus}=161\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}=1.61\times10^{5}\;\text{J mol}^{-1},
\qquad 
\Delta S^{\ominus}=250\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1},
\qquad 
T=700\;\text{K}
\]

\[
\Delta G^{\ominus}= \Delta H^{\ominus}-T\Delta S^{\ominus}
               =1.61\times10^{5}-700(250)
               =-1.4\times10^{4}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
K_{p}=e^{-\Delta G^{\ominus}/RT}=e^{14000/(8.314\times700)}
      =e^{2.405}\approx 11.1
\]

For the reaction  

\[
\ce{NH4Cl(s) <=> NH3(g) + HCl(g)}
\]

the equilibrium expression (solid activity = 1) is  

\[
K_{p}=P_{\ce{NH3}}\,P_{\ce{HCl}}=p^{2}
\]

Hence  

\[
p=\sqrt{K_{p}}\approx\sqrt{11.1}=3.33\;\text{bar}
\]

The total pressure is  

\[
P_{\text{tot}}=P_{\ce{NH3}}+P_{\ce{HCl}}=2p\approx 6.66\;\text{bar}
\]

Converting to kilopascals (1 bar = 100 kPa):

\[
P_{\text{tot}}\approx 6.66\times10^{2}\;\text{kPa}
\]

\[
\boxed{6.66\times10^{2}}\ \text{kPa}
\]

question: Following orbitals possess: (a) $2s$; (b) $4s$; (c) $3p$; (d) $5d$; (e) $1s$; (f) $4p$. Please give the sum of radial nodes as a digital number.
reference: Inorganic Chemistry _ Edition 4 -- Prof Catherine Housecroft, Alan G_ Sharpe -- 4th ed_, Harlow, England, New York, England, 2012 -- Pearson Education, 1.13
llm_answer:
The number of radial nodes for an orbital is given by  

\[
\text{radial nodes}=n-\ell-1,
\]

where \(n\) is the principal quantum number and \(\ell\) is the azimuthal quantum number (\(\ell=0\) for s, \(1\) for p, \(2\) for d).

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a) }2s &: n=2,\ \ell=0 \;\Rightarrow\; 2-0-1 = 1\\
\text{(b) }4s &: n=4,\ \ell=0 \;\Rightarrow\; 4-0-1 = 3\\
\text{(c) }3p &: n=3,\ \ell=1 \;\Rightarrow\; 3-1-1 = 1\\
\text{(d) }5d &: n=5,\ \ell=2 \;\Rightarrow\; 5-2-1 = 2\\
\text{(e) }1s &: n=1,\ \ell=0 \;\Rightarrow\; 1-0-1 = 0\\
\text{(f) }4p &: n=4,\ \ell=1 \;\Rightarrow\; 4-1-1 = 2
\end{aligned}
\]

Summing these radial nodes:

\[
1+3+1+2+0+2 = 9.
\]

\[
\boxed{9}
\]

question: The half - life of a first - order reaction at 400 K is 100 times that at 500 K. Try to estimate the activation energy of this reaction.
llm_answer:
For a first‑order reaction  

\[
t_{1/2}=\frac{\ln 2}{k}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
\frac{t_{1/2}(400)}{t_{1/2}(500)}=\frac{k_{500}}{k_{400}} .
\]

Given \(t_{1/2}(400)=100\,t_{1/2}(500)\),

\[
\frac{k_{500}}{k_{400}}=100 .
\]

Using the Arrhenius expression  

\[
k=A\exp\!\left(-\frac{E_a}{RT}\right),
\]

\[
\frac{k_{500}}{k_{400}}
   =\exp\!\Big[-\frac{E_a}{R}\Big(\frac1{500}-\frac1{400}\Big)\Big]
   =\exp\!\Big[\frac{E_a}{R}\,5\times10^{-4}\Big].
\]

Hence  

\[
100=\exp\!\Big[\frac{E_a}{R}\,5\times10^{-4}\Big]
\Longrightarrow 
\ln 100=\frac{E_a}{R}\,5\times10^{-4}.
\]

With \(\ln 100 = 4.6052\) and \(R = 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}=0.008314\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\),

\[
E_a=\frac{4.6052\;(0.008314)}{5\times10^{-4}}
      \;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
    \approx 7.66\times10^{1}\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{7.66\times10^{1}}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Boron nitride has a hexagonal layered structure similar to graphite (h-BN). The unit cell of h-BN is a right regular hexagonal prism, with cell parameters of b(side length) = \pu{1.47 Angstrom} and c(height) = \pu{6.66 Angstrom}. What is the volume of h-BN unit cell in \pu{cm^{3}}?
llm_answer:
The volume of a right regular hexagonal prism is  

\[
V = \text{(area of hexagonal base)}\times c
    = \left(\frac{3\sqrt3}{2}\,b^{2}\right)c .
\]

With \(b = 1.47\;\text{Å}\) and \(c = 6.66\;\text{Å}\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Area} &= \frac{3\sqrt3}{2}(1.47\;\text{Å})^{2}
            = \frac{3\sqrt3}{2}\times 2.1609\;\text{Å}^{2}
            \approx 5.614\;\text{Å}^{2},\\[4pt]
V &= 5.614\;\text{Å}^{2}\times 6.66\;\text{Å}
   \approx 37.4\;\text{Å}^{3}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Since \(1\;\text{Å}=10^{-8}\;\text{cm}\),  

\[
1\;\text{Å}^{3}=10^{-24}\;\text{cm}^{3},
\qquad
V = 37.4\times10^{-24}\;\text{cm}^{3}
   = 3.74\times10^{-23}\;\text{cm}^{3}.
\]

\[
\boxed{3.74\times10^{-23}}\ \text{cm}^{3}
\]

question: Dissolve 26.3 g of (CdSO_4) solid in 1000 g of water. Its freezing point is 0.285 K lower than that of pure water. Given that (k_f) of water is (1.86\ K¡¤kg¡¤mol^{-1}), calculate the degree of dissociation of (CdSO_4) in the solution and present the answer as a percentage.
llm_answer:
The freezing‑point depression is given by  

\[
\Delta T_f = i\,K_f\,m
\]

where  

* \(K_f = 1.86\ \text{K·kg·mol}^{-1}\) (water)  
* \(m = \dfrac{n_{\text{CdSO}_4}}{1\ \text{kg water}}\) (molality)  

Moles of \(\text{CdSO}_4\):

\[
n_{\text{CdSO}_4}= \frac{26.3\ \text{g}}{M_{\text{CdSO}_4}}
= \frac{26.3}{112.41+32.07+4(16.00)}
= \frac{26.3}{208.48}\ \text{mol}
\approx 0.1262\ \text{mol}
\]

Thus  

\[
m = 0.1262\ \text{mol·kg}^{-1}
\]

The observed depression is \(\Delta T_f = 0.285\ \text{K}\), so  

\[
i = \frac{\Delta T_f}{K_f\,m}
= \frac{0.285}{1.86 \times 0.1262}
\approx 1.213
\]

For a 1:1 electrolyte (\(\nu = 2\))  

\[
i = 1 + \alpha(\nu-1)=1+\alpha
\]

Hence  

\[
\alpha = i-1 \approx 0.213 \;(\text{fraction})
\]

Expressed as a percentage:

\[
\boxed{21.3}\%
\]

question: For the reaction:   $$\ce{2NaHCO_{3}(s)\rightleftharpoons Na_{2}CO_{3}(s) + CO_{2}(g) + H_{2}O(g)}$$   The standard molar reaction enthalpy is \(1.29\times10^{2}\ \text{kJ¡¤mol}^{-1}\). If \(K^{\ominus}=1.66\times10^{-5}\) at 303 K, try to calculate \(K^{\ominus}\) at 393 K.
llm_answer:
The temperature dependence of the equilibrium constant is given by the van’t Hoff equation  

\[
\ln\frac{K_{2}}{K_{1}}=-\frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{R}\left(\frac{1}{T_{2}}-\frac{1}{T_{1}}\right)
\]

where  

\[
\Delta H^{\circ}=1.29\times10^{2}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}=1.29\times10^{5}\ \text{J mol}^{-1},
\qquad 
R=8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1},
\qquad 
K_{1}=1.66\times10^{-5},
\qquad 
T_{1}=303\ \text{K},
\qquad 
T_{2}=393\ \text{K}.
\]

Calculate the temperature term  

\[
\frac{1}{T_{2}}-\frac{1}{T_{1}}=\frac{1}{393}-\frac{1}{303}
=0.0025445-0.0033003=-7.558\times10^{-4}\ \text{K}^{-1}.
\]

Insert the values:

\[
\ln\frac{K_{2}}{1.66\times10^{-5}}
=-\frac{1.29\times10^{5}}{8.314}\,(-7.558\times10^{-4})
=+11.735.
\]

Hence  

\[
\frac{K_{2}}{1.66\times10^{-5}}=e^{11.735}=1.25\times10^{5},
\qquad
K_{2}=1.66\times10^{-5}\times1.25\times10^{5}\approx2.07.
\]

\[
\boxed{K^{\ominus}(393\ \text{K})\approx 2.1}
\]

(The equilibrium constant is dimensionless.)

question: At a certain temperature, for the reaction:   $$\ce{H_{2}(g) + Br_{2}(g)\rightleftharpoons 2HBr(g)}$$   \(K_{c}=8.10\times10^{3}\). Calculate the equilibrium conversion of \(\ce{Br_{2}}\) in two cases:   1. The initial concentrations of \(\ce{H_{2}(g)}\) and \(\ce{Br_{2}(g)}\) are both \(1.00\ \text{mol¡¤dm}^{-3}\).   2. The initial concentrations of \(\ce{H_{2}(g)}\) and \(\ce{Br_{2}(g)}\) are \(10.00\ \text{mol¡¤dm}^{-3}\) and \(1.00\ \text{mol¡¤dm}^{-3}\) respectively.

Try to calculate the \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}\) of the reaction \(\ce{CO(g) + 2H_{2}(g)\xlongequal{´ß»¯¼Á} CH_{3}OH(l)}\) based on the thermodynamic data of the known reactions:   ¢Ù \(\ce{2C(graphite) + O_{2}(g) = 2CO(g)}\) \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}(1) = -221.0\ \text{kJ¡¤mol}^{-1}\)   ¢Ú \(\ce{C(graphite) + O_{2}(g) = CO_{2}(g)}\) \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}(2) = -393.5\ \text{kJ¡¤mol}^{-1}\)   ¢Û \(\ce{2CH_{3}OH(l) + 3O_{2}(g) = 2CO_{2}(g) + 4H_{2}O(l)}\) \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}(3) = -1452.2\ \text{kJ¡¤mol}^{-1}\)   ¢Ü \(\ce{2H_{2}(g) + O_{2}(g) = 2H_{2}O(l)}\) \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}(4) = -571.6\ \text{kJ¡¤mol}^{-1}\)
llm_answer:
\[
\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}\bigl(\ce{CO(g) + 2H_{2}(g) \rightarrow CH_{3}OH(l)}\bigr)
= -128.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: LiBr has a NaCl - type crystal structure and a density of (3.464\ \text{g¡¤cm}^{-3}). Calculate the distance (pm) between (\text{Li}^+) and (\text{Br}^-).
llm_answer:
The rock‑salt (NaCl) structure has each cation touching its nearest anion along the edge of the cubic unit cell, so  

\[
r_{\text{Li}^+}+r_{\text{Br}^-}= \frac{a}{2},
\]

where \(a\) is the lattice constant.

---

### 1.  Lattice constant from the density  

The unit cell contains \(Z = 4\) formula units of LiBr.  
Molar mass of LiBr  

\[
M = M_{\text{Li}}+M_{\text{Br}} = 6.94\;\text{g mol}^{-1}+79.904\;\text{g mol}^{-1}=86.844\;\text{g mol}^{-1}.
\]

Mass of one unit cell  

\[
m_{\text{cell}} = \frac{Z\,M}{N_{\!A}}
               = \frac{4\times 86.844\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}{6.02214076\times10^{23}\;\text{mol}^{-1}}
               = 5.768\times10^{-22}\;\text{g}.
\]

With the given density \(\rho = 3.464\;\text{g cm}^{-3}\),

\[
V_{\text{cell}} = \frac{m_{\text{cell}}}{\rho}
                = \frac{5.768\times10^{-22}\;\text{g}}{3.464\;\text{g cm}^{-3}}
                = 1.665\times10^{-22}\;\text{cm}^{3}.
\]

Since \(V_{\text{cell}} = a^{3}\),

\[
a = \left(1.665\times10^{-22}\;\text{cm}^{3}\right)^{1/3}
  = 5.50\times10^{-8}\;\text{cm}
  = 5.50\;\text{Å}.
\]

---

### 2.  Nearest‑neighbour distance  

\[
d_{\text{Li–Br}} = \frac{a}{2}= \frac{5.50\;\text{Å}}{2}=2.75\;\text{Å}.
\]

Converting Å to picometres (\(1\;\text{Å}=100\;\text{pm}\)):

\[
d_{\text{Li–Br}} = 2.75\times100\;\text{pm}=275\;\text{pm}.
\]

\[
\boxed{275}\ \text{pm}
\]

question: It is known that:   - For the electrode reaction \(\ce{Cu^{2+} + 2e^{-}=Cu}\), \(E^{\ominus}=0.34\ \text{V}\)   - For the electrode reaction \(\ce{Cu^{+} + e^{-}=Cu}\), \(E^{\ominus}=0.52\ \text{V}\)   - For the electrode reaction \(\ce{Cu^{2+} + Br^{-} + e^{-}=CuBr}\), \(E^{\ominus}=0.65\ \text{V}\)   Try to calculate the solubility - product constant \(K_{sp}^{\ominus}\) of \(\ce{CuBr}\).
llm_answer:
The dissolution equilibrium of copper(I) bromide is  

\[
\ce{CuBr(s) <=> Cu^{+} + Br^{-}}
\]

Its standard Gibbs energy can be obtained from the given electrode potentials.

1. **Potential for \(\ce{Cu^{2+}+e^- -> Cu^{+}}\)**  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G^{\circ}_{\ce{Cu^{2+}+2e^- -> Cu}} &= -2F(0.34)\\
\Delta G^{\circ}_{\ce{Cu^{+}+e^- -> Cu}}   &= -1F(0.52)\\[2pt]
\Delta G^{\circ}_{\ce{Cu^{2+}+e^- -> Cu^{+}}}
   &=\Delta G^{\circ}_{\ce{Cu^{2+}+2e^- -> Cu}}
     -\Delta G^{\circ}_{\ce{Cu^{+}+e^- -> Cu}}\\
   &=-0.68F+0.52F=-0.16F
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence  

\[
E^{\circ}_{\ce{Cu^{2+}+e^- -> Cu^{+}}}= \frac{-\Delta G^{\circ}}{F}=0.16\ \text{V}
\]

2. **Oxidation of solid CuBr**

\[
\ce{CuBr(s) -> Cu^{2+}+Br^-+e^-}\qquad
E^{\circ}_{\text{ox}} = -0.65\ \text{V}
\]

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}_{\text{ox}} = -F(-0.65)=+0.65F
\]

3. **Combine with the reduction above**

\[
\ce{Cu^{2+}+e^- -> Cu^{+}}\qquad
\Delta G^{\circ}_{\text{red}} = -F(0.16) = -0.16F
\]

Adding the two half‑reactions eliminates the electron and gives the overall dissolution reaction:

\[
\ce{CuBr(s) -> Cu^{+}+Br^{-}}
\]

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}_{\text{diss}} = 0.65F - 0.16F = 0.49F
\]

4. **Relation to the solubility product**

\[
\Delta G^{\circ} = -RT\ln K_{\text{sp}}
\]

\[
\ln K_{\text{sp}} = -\frac{0.49F}{RT}
          = -\frac{0.49\times 96485\ \text{J mol}^{-1}}
                  {8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\times 298\ \text{K}}
          \approx -19.1
\]

\[
K_{\text{sp}} = e^{-19.1}\approx 5\times10^{-9}
\]

\[
\boxed{5\times10^{-9}}
\]

question: It is known that at 298 K, the standard molar Gibbs free energy of formation \(\Delta_{f}G_{m}^{\ominus}\) of \(\ce{Ca(OH)_{2}(s)}\) is \(- 897.5\ \text{kJ¡¤mol}^{-1}\), and that of \(\ce{H_{2}O(l)}\) is \(-237.1\ \text{kJ¡¤mol}^{-1}\). The ion - product constant of water \(K_{w}^{\ominus}=1.00\times10^{-14}\). Try to calculate the electrode potential of the electrode \(\ce{Ca(OH)_{2}/Ca}\).
llm_answer:
The half‑reaction for the calcium electrode in contact with solid calcium hydroxide is  

\[
\ce{Ca(OH)2(s) + 2 e^- -> Ca(s) + 2 OH^- (aq)}
\]

The standard Gibbs free‑energy change for this reaction is  

\[
\Delta G^{\ominus}= \bigl[\,\Delta_f G^{\ominus}_{\ce{Ca}}+2\Delta_f G^{\ominus}_{\ce{OH^-}}\bigr]
                 -\Delta_f G^{\ominus}_{\ce{Ca(OH)2}}
\]

The standard Gibbs free energy of formation of \(\ce{OH^- (aq)}\) is obtained from the water dissociation equilibrium  

\[
\ce{H2O(l) -> H^+ (aq) + OH^- (aq)},\qquad 
\Delta G^{\ominus}= -RT\ln K_w
\]

\[
\Delta G^{\ominus}= - (8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(298\;\text{K})\ln(1.0\times10^{-14})
                 = +79.9\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

Since \(\Delta_f G^{\ominus}_{\ce{H^+}}=0\),

\[
\Delta_f G^{\ominus}_{\ce{OH^-}} = \Delta G^{\ominus} + \Delta_f G^{\ominus}_{\ce{H2O}}
                                 = 79.9\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1} - 237.1\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
                                 = -157.2\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

Now  

\[
\Delta G^{\ominus}= \bigl[0 + 2(-157.2\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1})\bigr] - (-897.5\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1})
                 = 583.1\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

The standard electrode potential follows from  

\[
E^{\ominus}= -\frac{\Delta G^{\ominus}}{nF}
\]

with \(n=2\) electrons and \(F=96485\;\text{C mol}^{-1}\):

\[
E^{\ominus}= -\frac{583.1\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}}{2(96485\;\text{C mol}^{-1})}
           = -3.02\;\text{V}
\]

\[
\boxed{-3.02}\ \text{V}
\]

question: It is known that for the electrode reaction \(\ce{Cu^{+} + e^{-}=Cu}\), \(E^{\ominus} = 0.52\ \text{V}\), and the solubility - product constant \(K_{sp}\) of \(\ce{CuCl}\) is \(1.7\times10^{-7}\). Try to calculate the standard electrode potential \(E^{\ominus}\) for the electrode reaction \(\ce{CuCl + e^{-}=Cu + Cl^{-}}\).
llm_answer:
The overall half‑reaction  

\[
\ce{CuCl(s) + e^- -> Cu(s) + Cl^-}
\]

can be written as the sum of  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{(i)}\;&\ce{CuCl(s) -> Cu^+ + Cl^-}\qquad K_{sp}=1.7\times10^{-7}\\[2pt]
\text{(ii)}\;&\ce{Cu^+ + e^- -> Cu(s)}\qquad E^{\ominus}=0.52\ \text{V}
\end{aligned}
\]

For a half‑reaction, \(\Delta G^{\ominus} = -nF E^{\ominus}\) (with \(n=1\)).  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G^{\ominus}_{\text{(ii)}} &= -F(0.52\ \text{V})\\
\Delta G^{\ominus}_{\text{(i)}} &= -RT\ln K_{sp}
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta G^{\ominus}_{\text{overall}} = -RT\ln K_{sp} - F(0.52\ \text{V})
\]

and  

\[
E^{\ominus}_{\text{overall}} = -\frac{\Delta G^{\ominus}_{\text{overall}}}{F}
      = \frac{RT}{F}\ln K_{sp}+0.52\ \text{V}.
\]

At \(25^{\circ}\text{C}\) (\(T=298\ \text{K}\))  

\[
\frac{RT}{F}= \frac{8.314\times298}{96485}=0.0257\ \text{V},
\qquad
\ln K_{sp}= \ln(1.7\times10^{-7})=-15.59.
\]

Thus  

\[
E^{\ominus}_{\text{overall}} = 0.0257(-15.59)+0.52
                           \approx -0.401+0.52
                           \approx 0.12\ \text{V}.
\]

\[
\boxed{0.12}\ \text{V}
\]

question: In a solution, the initial concentrations of \(\ce{Cu^{2+}}\) and \(\ce{NH_{3}¡¤H_{2}O}\) are \(0.20\ \text{mol¡¤dm}^{-3}\) and \(1.0\ \text{mol¡¤dm}^{-3}\) respectively. It is known that the stability constant \(K_{stable}^{\ominus}\) of \(\ce{[Cu(NH_{3})_{4}]^{2+}}\) is \(2.1\times10^{13}\). Try to calculate the residual concentration of \(\ce{Cu^{2+}}\) in the solution at equilibrium.
llm_answer:
The formation equilibrium is  

\[
\ce{Cu^{2+} + 4NH3 <=>[K] [Cu(NH3)4]^{2+}},\qquad 
K = 2.1\times10^{13}
\]

Let \(y\) be the concentration of the complex formed at equilibrium.  

\[
\begin{aligned}
[\ce{Cu^{2+}}]_{\text{eq}} &= 0.20 - y,\\
[\ce{NH3}]_{\text{eq}} &= 1.0 - 4y,\\
[\ce{[Cu(NH3)4]^{2+}}]_{\text{eq}} &= y .
\end{aligned}
\]

The stability constant gives  

\[
K=\frac{y}{(0.20-y)(1.0-4y)^{4}} .
\]

Because \(K\) is extremely large, essentially all copper is complexed; set  

\[
s = 0.20 - y \quad (\text{residual } \ce{Cu^{2+}}),\qquad s\ll0.20 .
\]

Then  

\[
y = 0.20 - s,\qquad 
1.0-4y = 1.0-4(0.20-s)=0.2+4s\approx0.2 .
\]

Substituting into the expression for \(K\):

\[
K \approx \frac{0.20}{s\,(0.2)^{4}}
      =\frac{0.20}{s\,(0.0016)}
      =\frac{125}{s}.
\]

Hence  

\[
s = \frac{125}{K}= \frac{125}{2.1\times10^{13}}
   \approx 5.95\times10^{-12}\ \text{mol dm}^{-3}.
\]

Thus the equilibrium concentration of free \(\ce{Cu^{2+}}\) is  

\[
\boxed{6.0\times10^{-12}}\ \text{mol dm}^{-3}.
\]

question: At \(1.013¡Á10^{5}\ \text{Pa}\) and \(373\ \text{K}\), \(18\ \text{g}\) of \(\ce{H_{2}O(l)}\) vaporizes into \(\ce{H_{2}O(g)}\), absorbing \(40.58\ \text{kJ}\) of heat. Try to calculate \(\Delta U\) for this process.
llm_answer:
The heat supplied at constant pressure is the enthalpy change  

\[
\Delta H = q_{p}= 40.58\ \text{kJ}
\]

For an ideal gas  

\[
\Delta H = \Delta U + \Delta (PV)=\Delta U + \Delta (nRT)
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta U = \Delta H - \Delta n\,RT
\]

The amount of water that vaporises is  

\[
n = \frac{18\ \text{g}}{M_{\ce{H2O}}}= \frac{18}{18.015}\ \text{mol}=0.999\ \text{mol}
\]

(Initially the liquid contributes essentially no gas, so \(\Delta n = +0.999\ \text{mol}\).)

Now  

\[
\Delta n\,RT = (0.999\ \text{mol})(8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(373\ \text{K})
           = 3.10\times10^{3}\ \text{J}=3.10\ \text{kJ}
\]

Finally  

\[
\Delta U = 40.58\ \text{kJ} - 3.10\ \text{kJ}= 37.48\ \text{kJ}
\]

\[
\boxed{37.48}\ \text{kJ}
\]

question: The solubility of \(\ce{Mg(OH)_{2}}\) in water is \(1.12\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol¡¤dm}^{-3}\). Try to calculate its solubility - product constant \(K_{sp}^{\ominus}\). If \(0.10\ \text{dm}^3\) of \(0.10\ \text{mol¡¤dm}^{-3}\) \(\ce{MgCl_{2}}\) solution is mixed with \(0.10\ \text{dm}^3\) of \(0.10\ \text{mol¡¤dm}^{-3}\) \(\ce{NH_{3}¡¤H_{2}O}\) solution, try to find out how many grams of \(\ce{NH_{4}Cl}\) solid need to be added to inhibit the precipitation of \(\ce{Mg(OH)_{2}}\).   It is known that the \(K_{b}^{\ominus}\) of \(\ce{NH_{3}¡¤H_{2}O}\) is \(1.8\times10^{-5}\).

The concentration of the solution of the sodium salt (NaX) of a monoprotic weak acid is \(0.2\ \text{mol¡¤dm}^{-3}\). Given that its pH is 9, try to calculate the dissociation equilibrium constant \(K_{a}^{\ominus}\) of this weak acid HX.
llm_answer:
For the salt NaX the anion X⁻ is the conjugate base of the weak acid HX.  
In water it undergoes the hydrolysis equilibrium  

\[
\ce{X^- + H2O <=> HX + OH^-}
\]

with the base‑dissociation constant  

\[
K_{\mathrm b}= \frac{[\ce{HX}][\ce{OH^-}]}{[\ce{X^-}]}\; .
\]

---

### 1.  Determine \([\ce{OH^-}]\) from the pH  

\[
\text{pH9\;\Longrightarrow\;\text{pOH}=14-9=5
\]

\[
[\ce{OH^-}]=10^{-\text{pOH}}=10^{-5}\ \text{mol·dm}^{-3}=x .
\]

Thus at equilibrium  

\[
[\ce{HX}]=x=10^{-5}\ \text{M},\qquad 
[\ce{X^-}]=C-x\approx C=0.20\ \text{M}
\]

(the change \(x\) is negligible compared with the initial concentration).

---

### 2.  Calculate \(K_{\mathrm b}\)

\[
K_{\mathrm b}= \frac{x^{2}}{C}
          =\frac{(10^{-5})^{2}}{0.20}
          =\frac{10^{-10}}{2.0\times10^{-1}}
          =5.0\times10^{-10}.
\]

---

### 3.  Relate \(K_{\mathrm b}\) to \(K_{\mathrm a}\)

\[
K_{\mathrm a}\,K_{\mathrm b}=K_{\mathrm w}=1.0\times10^{-14}
\]

\[
K_{\mathrm a}= \frac{K_{\mathrm w}}{K_{\mathrm b}}
            =\frac{1.0\times10^{-14}}{5.0\times10^{-10}}
            =2.0\times10^{-5}.
\]

---

\[
\boxed{2\times10^{-5}}
\]

question: At \(1.013¡Á10^{5}\ \text{Pa}\) and \(373\ \text{K}\), \(18\ \text{g}\) of \(\ce{H_{2}O(l)}\) vaporizes into \(\ce{H_{2}O(g)}\), absorbing \(40.58\ \text{kJ}\) of heat. Try to calculate \(\Delta S\) for this process.

It is known that the standard molar entropies \(S_{m}^{\ominus}\) of solid iodine \(\ce{I_{2}(s)}\) and iodine vapor \(\ce{I_{2}(g)}\) are \(116.1\ \text{J¡¤mol}^{-1}¡¤\text{K}^{-1}\) and \(260.7\ \text{J¡¤mol}^{-1}¡¤\text{K}^{-1}\) respectively, and the standard molar enthalpy of formation \(\Delta_{f}H_{m}^{\ominus}\) of iodine vapor is \(62.4\ \text{kJ¡¤mol}^{-1}\). Try to calculate the normal sublimation temperature of solid iodine.
llm_answer:
The sublimation equilibrium is  

\[
\ce{I2(s) -> I2(g)}
\]

At equilibrium \(\Delta G^{\ominus}=0\), thus  

\[
\Delta G^{\ominus}= \Delta H^{\ominus}-T\Delta S^{\ominus}=0
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
T=\frac{\Delta H^{\ominus}}{\Delta S^{\ominus}} .
\]

**Enthalpy change** (sublimation)

\[
\Delta_{\text{sub}}H^{\ominus}= \Delta_f H^{\ominus}\bigl[\ce{I2(g)}\bigr]-\Delta_f H^{\ominus}\bigl[\ce{I2(s)}\bigr]
=62.4\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}=6.24\times10^{4}\ \text{J mol}^{-1}.
\]

**Entropy change**

\[
\Delta_{\text{sub}}S^{\ominus}=S^{\ominus}\bigl[\ce{I2(g)}\bigr]-S^{\ominus}\bigl[\ce{I2(s)}\bigr]
=260.7-116.1=144.6\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}.
\]

**Sublimation temperature**

\[
T_{\text{sub}}=\frac{6.24\times10^{4}\ \text{J mol}^{-1}}{144.6\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}}
\approx 4.32\times10^{2}\ \text{K}.
\]

\[
\boxed{432}\ \text{]

The target reaction can be obtained by combining the two given reactions.

1. Halve reaction (1):
\[
\frac12\bigl(2\ce{MnO4^-}+10\ce{Cl^-}+16\ce{H^+}\rightarrow2\ce{Mn^{2+}}+5\ce{Cl2}+8\ce{H2O}\bigr)
\]
\[
\ce{MnO4^-}+5\ce{Cl^-}+8\ce{H^+}\rightarrow\ce{Mn^{2+}}+\tfrac52\ce{Cl2}+4\ce{H2O}
\qquad\Delta G^\circ_1'=-\tfrac12(142.0)= -71.0\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

2. Multiply reaction (2) by \( \tfrac52 \):
\[
\frac52\bigl(\ce{Cl2}+2\ce{Fe^{2+}}\rightarrow2\ce{Cl^-}+2\ce{Fe^{3+}}\bigr)
\]
\[
\tfrac52\ce{Cl2}+5\ce{Fe^{2+}}\rightarrow5\ce{Cl^-}+5\ce{Fe^{3+}}
\qquad\Delta G^\circ_2'=\tfrac52(-113.6)= -284.0\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

3. Add the two modified reactions. The \(\tfrac52\ce{Cl2}\) and \(5\ce{Cl^-}\) cancel, giving the desired overall reaction:
\[
\ce{MnO4^-}+5\ce{Fe^{2+}}+8\ce{H^+}\rightarrow\ce{Mn^{2+}}+5\ce{Fe^{3+}}+4\ce{H2O}
\]

4. The standard Gibbs energy change for the overall reaction is the sum:
\[
\Delta_r G^\circ = \Delta G^\circ_1' + \Delta G^\circ_2' = -71.0\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1} + (-284.0\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1})
= -355.0\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{-355.0}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: The pKa of methylammonium ion, CH3NH3 + , is 10.64. What is the percent ionization of a 0.20 M solution of methylamine, CH3NH2?
llm_answer:
The conjugate‑acid dissociation constant is  

\[
K_a = 10^{-\text{p}K_a}=10^{-10.64}=2.29\times10^{-11}
\]

so the base dissociation constant of methylamine is  

\[
K_b=\frac{K_w}{K_a}= \frac{1.0\times10^{-14}}{2.29\times10^{-11}}
      =4.36\times10^{-4}
\]

For the base equilibrium  

\[
\text{CH}_3\text{NH}_2 + \text{H}_2\text{O}\rightleftharpoons \text{CH}_3\text{NH}_3^{+}+ \text{OH}^{-}
\]

let \(x\) be the concentration of \(\text{OH}^-\) formed.  
With an initial base concentration \(C=0.20\ \text{M}\),

\[
K_b=\frac{x^2}{C-x}\;\Longrightarrow\;x^2+K_b x-K_b C=0
\]

\[
x=\frac{-K_b+\sqrt{K_b^{2}+4K_bC}}{2}
   =\frac{-4.36\times10^{-4}+\sqrt{(4.36\times10^{-4})^{2}+4(4.36\times10^{-4})(0.20)}}{2}
   =9.1\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}
\]

The percent ionization is  

\[
\%\,\text{ionization}= \frac{x}{C}\times100
                     =\frac{9.1\times10^{-3}}{0.20}\times100
                     \approx 4.6\%
\]

\[
\boxed{4.6\%}
\]

question: A strong base is used to titrate a monoprotic weak acid. When \(3.50\ \text{cm}^3\) of the strong base solution is added, the pH of the system is 4.15. When \(5.70\ \text{cm}^3\) of the strong base solution is added, the pH of the system is 4.44. Try to calculate the dissociation equilibrium constant of this weak acid.
llm_answer:
For a weak monoprotic acid \( \mathrm{HA} \) titrated with a strong base, before the equivalence point the solution is a buffer.  
The Henderson–Hasselbalch equation gives  

\[
\mathrm{pH}= \mathrm{p}K_a+\log\frac{n_{\mathrm{B}}}{n_{\mathrm{HA}}-n_{\mathrm{B}}}
\]

where  

* \(n_{\mathrm{HA}} = C_{\mathrm{HA}}V_0\) – initial moles of acid,  
* \(n_{\mathrm{B}} = C_{\mathrm{B}}V_{\mathrm{B}}\) – moles of base added.

Let  

\[
V_1 = 3.50\ \text{cm}^3,\qquad \mathrm{pH}_1 = 4.15,
\]
\[
V_2 = 5.70\ \text{cm}^3,\qquad \mathrm{pH}_2 = 4.44,
\]
\[
r = \frac{V_2}{V_1}= \frac{5.70}{3.50}=1.6286 .
\]

Denote \(x=n_{\mathrm{B},1}=C_{\mathrm{B}}V_1\) and \(y=\dfrac{n_{\mathrm{HA}}}{x}\).  
From the two Henderson–Hasselbalch equations:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{pH}_1 &= \mathrm{p}K_a+\log\frac{x}{n_{\mathrm{HA}}-x}
               = \mathrm{p}K_a+\log\frac{1}{y-1},\\[4pt]
\mathrm{pH}_2 &= \mathrm{p}K_a+\log\frac{rx}{n_{\mathrm{HA}}-rx}
               = \mathrm{p}K_a+\log\frac{r}{y-r}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Subtracting the two equations eliminates \(\mathrm{p}K_a\):

\[
\Delta\mathrm{pH}= \mathrm{pH}_2-\mathrm{pH}_1
= \log\!\left[\frac{r(y-1)}{y-r}\right].
\]

With \(\Delta\mathrm{pH}=4.44-4.15=0.29\),

\[
10^{0.29}= \frac{r(y-1)}{y-r}.
\]

Solving for \(y\):

\[
y = \frac{r\,(10^{0.29}-1)}{10^{0.29}-r}
   =\frac{1.6286\,(1.95-1)}{1.95-1.6286}
   \approx 4.82 .
\]

Now use either buffer point to obtain \(\mathrm{p}K_a\).  
Using the first point:

\[
\mathrm{p}K_a = \mathrm{pH}_1 - \log\frac{1}{y-1}
               = 4.15 - \log\!\left(\frac{1}{4.82-1}\right)
               = 4.15 + \log(3.82)
               \approx 4.73 .
\]

Hence  

\[
K_a = 10^{-\mathrm{p}K_a}=10^{-4.73}\approx 1.9\times10^{-5}.
\]

\[
\boxed{K_a \approx 1.9\times10^{-5}}
\]

question: What is the maximum concentration of lead(II) ions at equilibrium in a solution with pH = 10.50? The Ksp of Pb(OH)2 is 1.4 ¡ä 10-15.
llm_answer:
The solubility product expression for lead(II) hydroxide is  

\[
K_{sp}= [\text{Pb}^{2+}][\text{OH}^-]^2 .
\]

From the given pH:

\[
\text{pOH}=14-\text{pH}=14-10.50=3.50,
\qquad
[\text{OH}^-]=10^{-\text{pOH}}=10^{-3.5}=3.16\times10^{-4}\ \text{M}.
\]

Assuming the dissolution of \(\text{Pb(OH)}_2\) does not appreciably change the hydroxide concentration, we solve for \([\text{Pb}^{2+}]\):

\[
[\text{Pb}^{2+}]
= \frac{K_{sp}}{[\text{OH}^-]^2}
= \frac{1.4\times10^{-15}}{(3.16\times10^{-4})^{2}}
= \frac{1.4\t^{-15}}{1.0\times10^{-7}}
= 1.4\times10^{-8}\ \text{M}.
\]

\[
\boxed{1.4\times10^{-8}}\ \text{M}
\]

question: (\ce{SO_{2}Cl_{2}(g) = SO_{2}(g) + Cl_{2}(g)}\) is a first - order reaction. The rate constant \(k\) at a certain temperature is \(3.8¡Á10^{-5}\ \text{s}^{-1}\). After heating at this temperature for \(1.5\ \text{h}\), what is the degree of dissociation of \(\ce{SO_{2}Cl_{2}}\)?
llm_answer:
For a first‑order decomposition  

\[
\ce{SO2Cl2(g) -> SO2(g) + Cl2(g)}
\]

the concentration of the reactant after time \(t\) is  

\[
[\ce{SO2Cl2}] = [\ce{SO2Cl2}]_0 e^{-kt}.
\]

Hence the fraction that has dissociated (degree of dissociation \(\alpha\)) is  

\[
\alpha = 1-e^{-kt}.
\]

Given  

\[
k = 3.8\times10^{-5}\ \text{s}^{-1},\qquad 
t = 1.5\ \text{h}=1.5\times3600\ \text{s}=5400\ \text{s},
\]

\[
kt = (3.8\times10^{-5})(5400)=0.2052.
\]

\[
\alpha = 1-e^{-0.2052}=1-0.8145\approx0.1855.
\]

Expressed as a percentage:

\[
\alpha \times 100\% \approx 18.6\%.
\]

\[
\boxed{18.6}\%
\]

question: In a test of the selectivity of an electrocatalyst for the reduction of carbon dioxide to methanol, electrolysis is carried out with a constant current of 0.370 A for 155 minutes. Afterwards, the cathodic compartment of the cell is analyzed and is found to contain 5.30 ¡ä 10-3 mol CH3OH. What is the faradaic yield (the percent yield based on the current passed through the cell)?
llm_answer:
The faradaic yield is  

\[
\text{FY}=\frac{n_{\text{e}}F\,n_{\text{CH}_3\text{OH}}}{I t}\times 100\%
\]

where  

* \(n_{\text{e}} = 6\) e⁻ per mole CH₃OH,  
* \(F = 96485\ \text{C mol}^{-1}\),  
* \(n_{\text{CH}_3\text{OH}} = 5.30\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}\),  
* \(I = 0.370\ \text{A}\),  
* \(t = 155\ \text{min}=155\times60\ \text{s}=9.30\times10^{3}\ \text{s}\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
Q_{\text{theor}} &= 6 \times 96485\ \frac{\text{C}}{\text{mol}} \times 5.30\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol} \\
&= 3.07\times10^{3}\ \text{C} ,\\[4pt]
Q_{\text{actual}} &= I t = 0.370\ \text{A}\times 9.30\times10^{3}\ \text{s}=3.44\times10^{3}\ \text{C},\\[4pt]
\text{FY} &= \frac{3.07\times10^{3}}{3.44\times10^{3}}\times100\% \approx 8.92\times10^{1}\% .
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{89.2}\ \%
\]

question: If the half-life time, \( t_{1/2} \), of the initiator AIBN in an unknown solvent is 22.6 h at \( 60^\circ \text{C} \), calculate its dissociation rate constant, \( k_{\text{d}} \), in units of reciprocal seconds.
llm_answer:
The half‑life for a first‑order dissociation is related to the rate constant by  

\[
t_{1/2}= \frac{\ln 2}{k_{\text d}}\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;k_{\text d}= \frac{\ln 2}{t_{1/2}} .
\]

Convert the half‑life to seconds:

\[
t_{1/2}=22.6\;\text{h}=22.6\times 3600\;\text{s}=8.1360\times10^{4}\;\text{s}.
\]

Now calculate \(k_{\text d}\):

\[
k_{\text d}= \frac{0.693147}{8.1360\times10^{4}\;\text{s}}
          = 8.52\times10^{-6}\;\text{s}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{8.52\times10^{-6}} \ \text{s}^{-1}
\]

question: Silver ion reacts with ammonia to form a complex ion: Ag+ (aq) + 2 NH3(aq) = Ag(NH3)2 + (aq) In a certain solution at equilibrium at 298 K, [Ag+ ] = [NH3] = [Ag(NH3)2 + ] = C. What is ?Grxn at 298 K if [Ag+ ] = [NH3] = [Ag(NH3)2 + ] = 0.1C?
llm_answer:
The reaction quotient for  

\[
\text{Ag}^+ + 2\text{NH}_3 \rightleftharpoons \text{Ag(NH}_3)_2^+
\]

is  

\[
Q=\frac{[\text{Ag(NH}_3)_2^+]}{[\text{Ag}^+][\text{NH}_3]^2}.
\]

At equilibrium \([\text{Ag}^+]=[\text{NH}_3]=[\text{Ag(NH}_3)_2^+]=C\), so  

\[
K=\frac{C}{C\;C^{2}}=\frac{1}{C^{2}}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}= -RT\ln K = -RT\ln\!\left(\frac{1}{C^{2}}\right)=2RT\ln C .
\]

When the concentrations are each \(0.1C\),

\[
Q=\frac{0.1C}{(0.1C)(0.1C)^{2}}=\frac{100}{C^{2}} .
\]

The Gibbs energy change is  

\[
\Delta G = \Delta G^{\circ}+RT\ln Q
          = 2RT\ln C + RT\ln\!\left(\frac{100}{C^{2}}\right)
          = RT\ln 100 .
\]

With \(R = 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\) and \(T = 298\;\text{K}\),

\[
\Delta G = (8.314)(298)\,\ln 100
          = 2477.6\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\times 4.6052
          \approx 1.14\times10^{4}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
          = 11.4\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{11.4}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: A tensile strip of polystyrene that is 10 cm in length, 5 cm in width, and 2 cm in thickness is stretched to a length of 10.5 cm. Assuming that the sample is isotropic and deforms uniformly, calculate the resulting width after deformation.
llm_answer:
The volume of the strip is conserved during the deformation:

\[
V_0 = L_0\,w_0\,t_0 = 10\;\text{cm}\times5\;\text{cm}\times2\;\text{cm}=100\;\text{cm}^3 .
\]

Let the stretch ratios be  

\[
\lambda_L=\frac{L}{L_0}= \frac{10.5}{10}=1.05 ,\qquad 
\lambda_w=\frac{w}{w_0},\qquad 
\lambda_t=\frac{t}{t_0}.
\]

For an isotropic, incompressible material the product of the three stretch ratios equals unity:

\[
\lambda_L\,\lambda_w\,\lambda_t = 1 .
\]

Because the deformation is uniform in the transverse directions, \(\lambda_w=\lambda_t\). Hence

\[
\lambda_w^2 = \frac{1}{\lambda_L}\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
\lambda_w = \sqrt{\frac{1}{1.05}} \approx 0.976 .
\]

The new width is therefore

\[
w = \lambda_w\,w_0 = 0.976 \times 5\;\text{cm} \approx 4.88\;\text{cm}.
\]

\[
\boxed{4.88}\,\text{cm}
\]

question: Cesium chloride (M = 168.4) crystallizes in a primitive cubic unit cell with each cesium ion surrounded by eight chloride ions arranged in a cube. The density of solid CsCl is 3.988 g cm-3. What is the Cs¨CCl distance?
llm_answer:
The CsCl structure contains one formula unit per primitive cubic cell.  
The mass of one unit cell is  

\[
m_{\text{cell}}=\frac{M}{N_{\!A}}=\frac{168.4\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}{6.022\times10^{23}\ \text{mol}^{-1}}
               =2.80\times10^{-22}\ \text{g}.
\]

Using the given density \(\rho = 3.988\ \text{g cm}^{-3}\),

\[
Vtext{cell}}=\frac{m_{\text{cell}}}{\rho}
               =\frac{2.80\times10^{-22}\ \text{g}}{3.988\ \text{g cm}^{-3}}
               =7.01\times10^{-23}\ \text{cm}^{3}.
\]

Convert to cubic ångströms (\(1\ \text{cm}^{3}=10^{24}\ \text{Å}^{3}\)):

\[
V_{\text{cell}} = 7.01\times10^{-23}\times10^{24}=70.1\ \text{Å}^{3}.
\]

Since the cell is cubic, \(a^{3}=V_{\text{cell}}\), giving

\[
a = (70.1)^{1/3}\ \text{Å}\approx 4.12\ \text{Å}.
\]

In the CsCl lattice the Cs–Cl distance is half the body diagonal:

\[
d_{\text{Cs–Cl}} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\,a
                 = 0.8660 \times 4.12\ \text{Å}
                 \approx 3.57\ \text{Å}.
\]

Finally, \(1\ \text{Å}=100\ \text{pm}\),

\[
d_{\text{Cs–Cl}} \approx 3.57\times100\ \text{pm}=357\ \text{pm}.
\]

\[
\boxed{357}\ \text{pm}
\]

question: A tensile strip of polystyrene that is 10 cm in length, 5 cm in width, and 2 cm in thickness is stretched to a length of 10.5 cm. Assuming that the sample is isotropic and deforms uniformly, calculate the % volume change after deformation.
llm_answer:
The original volume of the strip is  

\[
V_0 = L_0 \, w_0 \, t_0 = (10\;\text{cm})(5\;\text{cm})(2\;\text{cm}) = 100\;\text{cm}^3 .
\]

The linear strain in the tensile direction is  

\[
\varepsilon = \frac{L_1-L_0}{L_0}= \frac{10.5-10}{10}=0.05\;(5\%).
\]

Assuming isotropic, uniform deformation, the same strain applies to the width and thickness:

\[
\begin{aligned}
w_1 &= w_0(1+\varepsilon)=5(1.05)=5.25\;\text{cm},\\
t_1 &= t_0(1+\varepsilon)=2(1.05)=2.10\;\text{cm}.
\end{aligned}
\]

The deformed volume is  

\[
V_1 = L_1 w_1 t_1 = (10.5)(5.25)(2.10)=115.7625\;\text{cm}^3 .
\]

The volume change is  

\[
\Delta V = V_1 - V_0 = 115.7625 - 100 = 15.7625\;\text{cm}^3 .
\]

Hence the percent volume change is  

\[
\%\,\Delta V = \frac{\Delta V}{V_0}\times 100\% = \frac{15.7625}{100}\times100\% = 15.7625\% \approx 15.8\%.
\]

\[
\boxed{15.8}\ \%
\]

question: Molten polystyrene flows through a circular tube at \(210^\circ\text{C}\) under a pressure drop of 1,000 psi. Given that the inside diameter of the tube is 0.25 in. and that the tube is 3 in. in length, calculate the following: the (nominal) shear stress at the wall in units of \(\text{N m}^{-2}\)
llm_answer:
The wall shear stress for pressure‑driven flow in a circular tube is  

\[
\tau_w=\frac{\Delta P\,R}{2L},
\]

where  

* \(\Delta P = 1000\;\text{psi}=1000(6894.757\;\text{Pa})=6.894757\times10^{6}\;\text{Pa}\),  
* tube diameter \(d =0.25\;\text{in}=0.25(0.0254\;\text{m})=6.35\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}\) → radius \(R = d/2 = 3.175\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}\),  
* length \(L =3\;\text{in}=3(0.0254\;\text{m})=7.62\times10^{-2}\;\text{m}\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
\tau_w &= \frac{(6.894757\times10^{6}\,\text{Pa})(3.175\times10^{-3}\,\text{m})}
               {2(7.62\times10^{-2}\,\text{m})}  \\[4pt]
       &\approx \frac{2.1891\times10^{4}\,\text{Pa·m}}{0.1524\,\text{m}} \\[4pt]
       &\approx 1.44\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{1.44\times10^{5}}\ \text{N m}^{-2}
\]

question: Styrene is polymerized by free-radical mechanism in solution. The initial monomer and initiator concentrations are 1 \( M \) (molar) and 0.001 \( M \), respectively. At the polymerization temperature of \( 60^\circ\text{C} \), the initiator efficiency is 0.30. The rate constants at the polymerization temperature are as follows:   \[ \begin{align*} k_{\text{d}} &= 1.2 \times 10^{-5} \ \text{s}^{-1} \\ k_{\text{p}} &= 176 \ M^{-1} \text{s}^{-1} \\ k_{\text{t}} &= 7.2 \times 10^7 \ M^{-1} \text{s}^{-1} \\ \end{align*} \]   Given this information, determine the following:   Rate of initiation at 1 min and at 16.6 h
Calculate the shear modulus (GPa) of a polymer sample in a torsion pendulum with a period of 1.0 sec. The specimen is 10 cm long, 2 cm wide, and 7.5 mm thick and the moment of inertia is 5000 g¡¤cm?.
llm_answer:
The period of a torsional pendulum is  

\[
T = 2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I}{\kappa}}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
\kappa = \frac{4\pi^{2}I}{T^{2}}
\]

where \(I\) is the moment of inertia of the attached mass and \(\kappa\) is the torsional stiffness of the specimen.

---

### 1.  Torsional stiffness  

\[
I = 5000\;\text{g·cm}^{2}=5.0\times10^{-4}\;\text{kg·m}^{2}
\]

\[
\kappa = \frac{4\pi^{2}(5.0\times10^{-4})}{(1.0\;\text{s})^{2}}
        = 1.974\times10^{-2}\;\text{N·m rad}^{-1}
\]

---

### 2.  Torsional constant of a rectangular bar  

For a rectangular cross‑section (\(b\ge h\))

\[
J = b\,h^{3}\Bigl[\frac13-0.21\frac{h}{b}\Bigl(1-\frac{h^{4}}{12b^{4}}\Bigr)\Bigr]
\]

\[
b = 2.0\;\text{cm},\qquad h = 0.75\;\text{cm},\qquad 
\frac{h}{b}=0.375
\]

\[
J = 2.0(0.75)^{3}\Bigl[\frac13-0.21(0.375)\Bigl(1-\frac{0.375^{4}}{12}\Bigr)\Bigr]
   = 0.215\;\text{cm}^{4}=2.15\times10^{-9}\;\text{m}^{4}
\]

---

### 3.  Shear modulus  

The torsional stiffness of the bar is  

\[
\kappa = \frac{GJ}{L}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
G = \frac{\kappa L}{J}
\]

with \(L = 10\;\text{cm}=0.10\;\text{m}\):

\[
G = \frac{(1.974\times10^{-2})(0.10)}{2.15\times10^{-9}}
    = 9.18\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa}
\]

\[
G = 0.918\;\text{MPa}
\]

---

\[
\boxed{0.92}\ \text{MPa}
\]

question: It is known that for the acid - dissociation equilibrium constants of \(H_2S\) aqueous solution, \(K_1 = 1.1\times10^{-7}\) and \(K_2 = 1.3\times10^{-13}\), and the solubility - product constant \(K_{sp}^{\ominus}\) of \(CuS\) is \(6.3\times10^{-36}\).   The electrode reactions and their standard electrode potentials are:   - \(\ce{NO^{-}_{3} + 4H^{+} + 3e^{-}=NO + 2H_{2}O}\) \(E^{\ominus}=0.96\ \text{V}\)   - \(\ce{S + 2H^{+} + 2e^{-}=H_{2}S}\) \(E^{\ominus}=0.14\ \text{V}\)   Try to calculate the equilibrium constant \(K^{\ominus}\) for the reaction \(\ce{3CuS + 2NO^{-}_{3} + 8H^{+}=3Cu^{2 + } + 2NO + 3S + 4H_{2}O}\).
llm_answer:
The overall reaction  

\[
\ce{3CuS(s) + 2NO3^- + 8H^+ -> 3Cu^{2+} + 2NO + 3S(s) + 4H2O}
\]

can be built from three elementary equilibria  

1. **Dissolution of CuS**  

\[
\ce{CuS(s) <=> Cu^{2+} + S^{2-}},\qquad K_{sp}=6.3\times10^{-36}
\]

For three moles  

\[
K_{A}=K_{sp}^{3}=(6.3\times10^{-36})^{3}=2.5\times10^{-106}
\]

2. **Acid‑base equilibrium that converts \(\ce{S^{2-}}\) into \(\ce{H2S}\)**  

\[
\ce{S^{2-}+2H^+ <=> H2S},\qquad 
K_{B}= \frac{1}{K_{1}K_{2}}=
\frac{1}{(1.1\times10^{-7})(1.3\times10^{-13})}=7.0\times10^{19}
\]

For three moles  

\[
K_{B}^{3}=(7.0\times10^{19})^{3}=3.43\times10^{59}
\]

3. **Redox step**  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Oxidation:}&\quad \ce{H2S -> S + 2H^+ + 2e^-}\qquad E^{\circ}_{\text{ox}}=-0.14\ \text{V}\\
\text{Reduction:}&\quad \ce{NO3^- + 4H^+ + 3e^- -> NO + 2H2O}\qquad E^{\circ}_{\text{red}}=0.96\ \text{V}
\end{aligned}
\]

Multiplying the oxidation by 3 and the reduction by 2 gives a net transfer of  
\(n=6\) electrons. The cell potential is  

\[
E^{\circ}_{\text{cell}} = E^{\circ}_{\text{red}}-E^{\circ}_{\text{ox}}
=0.96-0.14 =0.82\ \text{V}
\]

Hence  

\[
\log_{10}K_{C}= \frac{nE^{\circ}_{\text{cell}}}{0.05916}
= \frac{6(0.82)}{0.05916}= 83.2
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
K_{C}=10^{83.2}
\]

---

### Overall equilibrium constant  

\[
K^{\circ}=K_{A}\,K_{B}^{3}\,K_{C}
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\log_{10}K^{\circ}&=
\log_{10}(2.5imes10^{-106})+
\log_{10}(3.43\times10^{59})+
83.2\\[2mm]
&= (-105.602)+(59.535)+83.2\\
&= 37.13
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
K^{\circ}=10^{37.13}\approx 1.4\times10^{37}
\]

\[
\boxed{1.4\times10^{37}}
\]

question: An asymmetric hollow fiber of polysulfone has a surface pore area, \( A_3/A_2 \), of \( 1.9 \times 10^{-6} \) and an effective skin thickness of 1000 ?. If the fiber is coated with a \( 1-\mu\text{m} \) layer of silicone rubber, calculate the effective \( P/\ell \) for the coated membrane for \( \text{CO}_2 \) and the permselectivity for \( \text{CO}_2/\text{CH}_4 \).
If the maximum in the $\alpha$-loss modulus of polystyrene at 1 Hz occurs at 373 K, at what temperature would the maximum occur at 110 Hz if the activation energy for this relaxation is 840 kJ mol???
llm_answer:
The condition for the loss‑modulus maximum is \(\omega \tau =1\) with an Arrhenius relaxation time  

\[
\tau = \tau_{0}\exp\!\left(\frac{E_a}{RT}\right).
\]

For two frequencies \(f_1\) and \(f_2\) ( \(\omega =2\pi f\) ) the pre‑exponential factor \(\tau_{0}\) cancels:

\[
\frac{E_a}{R}\!\left(\frac{1}{T_2}-\frac{1}{T_1}\right)=\ln\!\left(\frac{f_1}{f_2}\right).
\]

Hence  

\[
\frac{1}{T_2}= \frac{1}{T_1}+ \frac{R}{E_a}\ln\!\left(\frac{f_1}{f_2}\right),
\qquad
T_2=\frac{1}{\displaystyle \frac{1}{T_1}+ \frac{R}{E_a}\ln\!\left(\frac{f_1}{f_2}\right)} .
\]

Insert the data  

\[
\begin{aligned}
T_1 &= 373\ \text{K},\\
f_1 &= 1\ \text{Hz},\qquad f_2 = 110\ \text{Hz},\\
E_a &= 840\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}=8.40\times10^{5}\ \text{J mol}^{-1},\\
R &= 8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\ln\!\left(\frac{f_1}{f_2}\right)=\ln\!\left(\frac{1}{110}\right)=-4.7005,
\qquad
\frac{}{E_a}= \frac{8.314}{8.40\times10^{5}}=9.898\times10^{-6}\ \text{K}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\frac{1}{T_2}= \frac{1}{373}+ (9.898\times10^{-6})(-4.7005)
               =0.00268096-0.00004653
               =0.00263444\ \text{K}^{-1}.
\]

\[
T_2 = \frac{1}{0.00263444}\approx 3.80\times10^{2}\ \text{K}=379.5\ \text{K}.
\]

Rounded to the nearest kelvin:

\[
\boxed{380}\ \text{K}
\]

question: Assume that a polyesterification is conducted in the absence of solvent or catalyst and that the monomers are present in stoichiometric ratios. Calculate the time (min) required to obtain a number-average degree of polymerization of 50 given that the initial dicarboxylic acid concentration is \( 3 \ \text{mol L}^{-1} \) and that the polymerization rate constant is \( 10^{-2} \ \text{L mol}^{-1} \text{s}^{-1} \).

Assume all processes take place at \pu{298 K}. The enthalpy change of formation of \ce{CH4(g)} is \pu{-74.8 kJ mol^{-1}} and of \ce{H2O(l)} is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the standard enthalpy change of combustion of \ce{H2} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?

The length of an ideal rubber band is increased 100% to 12.0 cm at \(23^\circ\text{C}\). Stress on this rubber band increases by 0.2 MPa when it is heated to \(30^\circ\text{C}\) at 100% elongation. What is its tensile modulus in MPa at \(23^\circ\text{C}\) when it is stretched 2%?
llm_answer:
The stress of an ideal rubber band is proportional to the absolute temperature \(T\) and to the function \((\lambda-\lambda^{-2})\) of the stretch ratio \(\lambda\) :

\[
\sigma = G\bigl(\lambda-\lambda^{-2}\bigr),\qquad 
G=nRT\;(\text{shear modulus})
\]

---

### 1.  Determine the stress at \(23^{\circ}\text{C}\) for 100 % elongation  

At 100 % elongation the stretch ratio is  

\[
\lambda = 1+\varepsilon = 1+1 = 2 .
\]

Hence  

\[
\sigma_{23}=G\bigl(2-2^{-2}\bigr)=G\,(2-\tfrac14)=1.75\,G .
\]

When the temperature is raised from \(23^{\circ}\text{C}\) (\(T_1=296\;\text{K}\)) to \(30^{\circ}\text{C}\) (\(T_2=303\;\text{K}\)) at the same strain, the stress increases by  

\[
\Delta\sigma =0.20\;\text{MPa}.
\]

Because \(G\propto T\),

\[
\frac{\sigma_{30}}{\sigma_{23}}=\frac{T_2}{T_1}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\sigma_{30}= \sigma_{23}\frac{T_2}{T_1}.
\]

Thus  

\[
\Delta\sigma =\sigma_{23}\!\leftfrac{T_2}{T_1}-1\right)
\Longrightarrow
\sigma_{23}= \frac{\Delta\sigma}{\dfrac{T_2}{T_1}-1}
          =\frac{0.20}{\dfrac{303}{296}-1}
          =\frac{0.20}{\dfrac{7}{296}}
          \approx 8.46\;\text{MPa}.
\]

---

### 2.  Find the shear modulus \(G\) at \(23^{\circ}\text{C}\)

\[
G = \frac{\sigma_{23}}{1.75}
   =\frac{8.46}{1.75}
   \approx 4.83\;\text{MPa}.
\]

---

### 3.  Tensile (Young’s) modulus for small strains  

For small strains (\(\varepsilon\ll1\)), expand \(\lambda=1+\varepsilon\):

\[
\lambda-\lambda^{-2}\approx (1+\varepsilon)-\bigl(1-2\varepsilon\bigr)=3\varepsilon .
\]

Hence  

\[
\sigma \approx G\,(3\varepsilon)=E\,\varepsilon,
\qquad\text{so}\qquad
E = 3G .
\]

Therefore  

\[
E = 3(4.83\;\text{MPa}) \approx 14.5\;\text{MPa}.
\]

---

\[
\boxed{14.5}\ \text{MPa}
\]

question: An adult poisoned by a nerve agent requires an hourly dose of \pu{3 mmol} of Pralidoxime (PAM) for every kilogram of body mass. The molar mass of PAM is \pu{172.612 g mol^{-1}}. What is the mass, in grams, of PAM required for an \pu{80 kg} person over a treatment period of \pu{24 h}?
llm_answer:
The required mass of Pralidoxime is  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Dose per hour} &= 3\;\text{mmol}\,\text{kg}^{-1}\times 80\;\text{kg}=240\;\text{mmol h}^{-1},\\[4pt]
\text{Total dose for 24 h} &=240\;\text{mmol h}^{-1}\times 24\;\text{h}=5760\;\text{mmol}=5.76\;\text{mol},\\[4pt]
\text{Mass required} &=5.76\;\text{mol}\times 172.612\;\frac{\text{g}}{\text{mol}}\\
&=9.94\times10^{2}\;\text{g}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{9.94\times10^{2}}\ \text{g}
\]

question: The 1% secant modulus of a polystyrene sample is 3 GPa. What is the nominal stress (MPa) of this sample at a nominal strain of 0.01?
llm_answer:
The secant modulus \(E_{\text{sec}}\) relates stress \(\sigma\) and strain \(\varepsilon\) by  

\[
E_{\text{sec}} = \frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon}.
\]

Thus  

\[
\sigma = E_{\text{sec}}\;\varepsilon.
\]

Given \(E_{\text{sec}} = 3\ \text{GPa}=3000\ \text{MPa}\) and \(\varepsilon = 0.01\),

\[
\sigma = 3000\ \text{MPa}\times 0.01 = 30\ \text{MPa}.
\]

\[
\boxed{30}\ \text{MPa}
\]

question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{H2} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
llm_answer:
The reaction  

\[
\ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}
\]

has the equilibrium constant  

\[
K_{p}=0.64=\frac{P_{\ce{CO2}}P_{\ce{H2}}}{P_{\ce{CO}}P_{\ce{H2O}}}
\]

For an ideal‑gas mixture the partial pressures are proportional to mole numbers, and because the total number of moles stays constant (2 mol reactants → 2 mol products) the total pressure cancels:

\[
K_{p}= \frac{n_{\ce{CO2}}\,n_{\ce{H2}}}{n_{\ce{CO}}\,n_{\ce{H2O}}}
\]

Let \(\xi\) be the extent of the forward reaction.  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\ce{CO}} &= 40-\xi\\
n_{\ce{H2O}} &= 40-\xi\\
n_{\ce{CO2}} &= 20+\xi\\
n_{\ce{H2}} &= 20+\xi
\end{aligned}
\]

Insert these expressions into the equilibrium expression:

\[
0.64 = \frac{(20+\xi)^2}{(40-\xi)^2}
\]

\[
\frac{20+\xi}{40-\xi}= \sqrt{0.64}=0.8
\]

\[
20+\xi = 0.8(40-\xi)=32-0.8\xi
\]

\[
1.8\xi = 12 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad \xi = \frac{12}{1.8}= \frac{20}{3}=6.67\ \text{mol}
\]

The increase in the amount of \(\ce{H2}\) (the amount that leaves the reactor) is exactly the reaction extent \(\xi\).

\[
\boxed{6.67}\ \text{mol}
\]

question: What is the oxidation number of hydrogen in the reactants of Sabatier reaction?
llm_answer:
In the Sabatier reaction  

\[
\mathrm{CO_2 + 4\,H_2 \;\longrightarrow\; CH_4 + 2\,H_2O},
\]

the reactants containing hydrogen are molecular hydrogen, \(\mathrm{H_2}\).  
Hydrogen in its elemental (diatomic) form has an oxidation number of  

\[
\boxed{0}
\]

question: Avogadro's constant is \pu{6.02E23 mol^{-1}}. Gold has only one isotope, which has a relative mass of 197. The density of gold is \pu{19.3 g cm-3}. What is the mass (in \pu{g}) of one gold atom?
Lactic acid has an acid dissociation constant, $K_a$, of \pu{1.38E-4}. What is the pKa of lactic acid?
llm_answer:
The pKa is defined by  

\[
\mathrm{p}K_a = -\log_{10} K_a
\]

For \(K_a = 1.38\times10^{-4}\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{p}K_a &= -\log_{10}\!\left(1.38\times10^{-4}\right) \\
&= -\bigl[\log_{10}(1.38)+\log_{10}(10^{-4})\bigr] \\
&= -\bigl[0.1399-4\bigr] \\
&= 4-0.1399 \\
&\approx 3.86
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{3.86}
\]

question: The energy released when \pu{1 L} of the E10 fuel is burnt is \pu{30680 kJ} and the energy released when \pu{1 L} of the E5 fuel is burnt is \pu{31170 kJ}. Taking the energy released from burning \pu{1 L} of E5 as \pu{100 %}, what is the percentage of the energy released from burning \pu{1 L} of E10 fuel?
The density of pure water is \pu{1 g cm^{-3}}. What is its concentration in \pu{mol dm^{-3}}?
llm_answer:
The density of water is  

\[
\rho = 1\;\text{g cm}^{-3}.
\]

1. Convert the volume unit from \(\text{cm}^{3}\) to \(\text{dm}^{3}\):

\[
1\;\text{dm}=10\;\text{cm}\;\Longrightarrow\;1\;\text{dm}^{3}= (10\;\text{cm})^{3}=1000\;\text{cm}^{3}.
\]

Thus  

\[
1\;\text{cm}^{3}=10^{-3}\;\text{dm}^{3}.
\]

2. Express the mass of water per cubic decimetre:

\[
\rho = 1\;\frac{\text{g}}{\text{cm}^{3}} = \frac{1\;\text{g}}{10^{-3}\;\text{dm}^{3}}
      = 1000\;\frac{\text{g}}{\text{dm}^{3}}.
\]

3. Use the molar mass of water, \(M_{\text{H}_2\text{O}} = 18.015\;\text{g mol}^{-1}\), to find the amount of substance per dm³:

\[
c = \frac{1000\;\text{g dm}^{-3}}{18.015\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}
    = 55.5\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}\;(\text{to three significant figures}).
\]

\[
\boxed{55.5\ \text{mol dm}^{-3}}
\]

question: The mass of one gold atom is \pu{3.27E-22 g} and the density of gold is \pu{19.3 g cm^{-3}}. What is the molar volume of gold in \pu{cm^{3} mol^{-1}}?
llm_answer:
The molar volume \(V_{\mathrm m}\) is obtained from the molar mass \(M\) divided by the density \(\rho\):

\[
V_{\mathrm m}= \frac{M}{\rho}
\]

---

**1.  Molar mass from the mass of a single atom**

\[
M = m_{\text{atom}}\;N_{\!A}
   = (3.27\times10^{-22}\,\text{g})\;(6.02214076\times10^{23}\,\text{mol}^{-1})
   = 1.9692\times10^{2}\,\text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
M \approx 196.9\;\text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

---

**2.  Molar volume**

\[
V_{\mathrm m}= \frac{196.9\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}{19.3\;\text{g cm}^{-3}}
            = 10.2\;\text{cm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

---

\[
\boxed{10.2}\ \text{cm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Give your best estimate for the weight fraction of plasticizer required to lower the \( T_{\text{g}} \) of poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC) to \( 30^\circ\text{C} \). Assume that the \( T_{\text{g}} \) of PVC is 356 K and that of the plasticizer is 188 K. No other information is available.
llm_answer:
The Fox equation for the glass‑transition temperature of a binary polymer blend is  

\[
\frac{1}{T_g}=w_1\frac{1}{T_{g1}}+w_2\frac{1}{T_{g2}},\qquad 
w_1+w_2=1
\]

where  

* \(T_{g1}=356\ \text{K}\) – glass‑transition temperature of PVC,  
* \(T_{g2}=188\ \text{K}\) – glass‑transition temperature of the plasticizer,  
* \(T_g=303\ \text{K}\) – desired glass‑transition temperature (30 °C).

Let \(w_2\) be the weight fraction of plasticizer.  Substituting \(w_1=1-w_2\),

\[
\frac{1}{303}= \frac{1-w_2}{356}+ \frac{w_2}{188}
           =\frac{1}{356}+w_2\!\left(\frac{1}{188}-\frac{1}{356}\right).
\]

Solve for \(w_2\):

\[
w_2=\frac{\displaystyle\frac{1}{303}-\frac{1}{356}}
          {\displaystyle\frac{1}{188}-\frac{1}{356}}.
\]

Evaluating the reciprocals  

\[
\frac{1}{303}=0.00330033,\qquad
\frac{1}{356}=0.00280899,\qquad
\frac{1}{188}=0.00531915\;(\text{K}^{-1}),
\]

\[
\text{numerator}=0.00330033-0.00280899=0.00049134,
\qquad
\text{denominator}=0.00531915-0.00280899=0.00251016,
\]

\[
w_2=\frac{0.00049134}{0.00251016}\approx0.196.
\]

Thus the required plasticizer content is about \(19.6\%\) by weight.

\[
\boxed{19.6}\ \text{wt\%}
\]

question: The standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{NaOH + HCl -> NaCl + H2O} is \pu{-56.7 kJ mol^{-1}}, the standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{SiO2 + 6HF -> H2SiF6 + 2H2O} is \pu{-100.3 kJ mol^{-1}} and the standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{NaOH + HF -> H2O + NaF} is \pu{-61.5 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{SiO2 + 6NaF + 6HCl -> H2SiF6 + 6NaCl + 2H2O} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?

At \pu{25 deg C}, the partial pressure of \ce{CO2} gas in a \pu{250 cm^{3}} fizzy drink can is \pu{3 atm}. The Henry's law constant for \ce{CO2} is \pu{0.033 mol dm^{-3} atm^{-1}}. The can contains only \pu{1.09 g} of \ce{CO2} as a gas. What is the pressure in the can at \pu{25 deg C} in \pu{kPa}?

The enthalpy of combustion of ethanol is \pu{-1276 kJ mol^{-1}} and the enthalpy of combustion of an isomer of octane is \pu{-5144 kJ mol^{-1}}. Assume that \pu{1 L} of E10 fuel contains \pu{100 mL} of ethanol and \pu{900 mL} of octane isomers. The density of pure ethanol is \pu{0.789 g cm^{-3}} and the density of pure octane isomers is \pu{0.703 g cm^{-3}}. What is the energy, in \pu{kJ}, released when \pu{1 L} of the E10 fuel is burnt?
The molar volume of gold is \pu{10.2 cm^{3} mol^{-1}}. The gold atoms occupy 74 % of the volume of the cubic unit cell. What is the radius of the gold atom in \pu{\A}?
llm_answer:
The gold crystal is face‑centered cubic (FCC).  
In an FCC unit cell  

* number of atoms per cell \(=4\)  
* the packing (atomic) fraction \(=0.74\)  

---

### 1.  Unit‑cell volume from the molar volume  

The molar volume \(V_{\mathrm m}=10.2\;\mathrm{cm^{3}\,mol^{-1}}\) gives the volume per atom  

\[
V_{\text{atom}}=\frac{V_{\mathrm m}}{N_{\!A}}
\]

so the volume of one unit cell is  

\[
V_{\text{cell}}=4\,V_{\text{atom}}=4\frac{V_{\mathrm m}}{N_{\!A}} .
\]

---

### 2.  Relating the lattice constant \(a\) to the atomic radius \(r\)

For an FCC lattice the atoms touch along a face diagonal:

\[
4r=\sqrt{2}\,a\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad a=2\sqrt{2}\,r .
\]

Hence  

\[
V_{\text{cell}}=a^{3}=(2\sqrt{2}\,r)^{3}=16\sqrt{2}\,r^{3}.
\]

---

### 3.  Solve for \(r\)

Equating the two expressions for the cell volume:

\[
